description: The ITIL:Release, Control, & Validation show centers around the 7 processes within the ITIL Service Transition Publication. 108
00:06:04.563 --> 00:06:09.243

110
00:06:14.511 --> 00:06:16.330

00:06:21.330 --> 00:06:26.092

113

114
00:06:31.030 --> 00:06:35.034
10, that would be the sweet

115
00:06:35.034 --> 00:06:38.925

116
00:06:38.925 --> 00:06:43.180

more five answers later on, on the exam.

117
00:06:43.180 --> 00:06:45.370
So they are challenging.

118
00:06:45.370 --> 00:06:46.570
They are fair.

119
00:06:46.570 --> 00:06:50.040

121
00:06:51.970 --> 00:06:56.910

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Terry begin with a review of the ITIL foundations.  They focus in on the basic service model and vocabulary that a viewer is expected to understand and know.  They compare services to solutions and give different examples.  These foundational concepts of ITIL are built around customer needs.  This is important for those desiring to move deeper into the Release, Control and Validation.

00:26:17.950 --> 00:26:19.780
What does IT do for them?

511
00:26:21.070 --> 00:26:24.150
I was amazed, I mean I guess I shouldn't
be, I've been in IT for many years.

512
00:26:24.150 --> 00:26:27.620
But the things that IT can do for
an oil company.

513
00:26:27.620 --> 00:26:31.410
They can put an instrument on the bottom
of a drill and it can go down and

514
00:26:31.410 --> 00:26:34.680
discover things and send it back.

515
00:26:34.680 --> 00:26:38.530
Send that real time information
back to a central repository so

516
00:26:38.530 --> 00:26:42.390
it can be looked at by a chemist or by
a geophysicists or those types of folks.

517
00:26:42.390 --> 00:26:45.610
So you got the smart people,
the chemist, geophysicists and

518
00:26:45.610 --> 00:26:49.570
here is IT delivering data,
they can transform that into animation and

519
00:26:49.570 --> 00:26:51.780
make some wise decisions based on it.

520
00:26:51.780 --> 00:26:56.390
So again,
IT assets being added to customer assets.

521
00:26:56.390 --> 00:27:00.450
Service asserts, customer assets
together forming some value.

522
00:27:03.750 --> 00:27:06.540
So that's a good place to stop for
now, I think.

523
00:27:06.540 --> 00:27:08.470
>> That sounds great, Terry.

524
00:27:08.470 --> 00:27:12.860
As we continue on, we're just showing you
some of the basic things that we need to

525
00:27:12.860 --> 00:27:15.530
ensure that we can review and

526
00:27:15.530 --> 00:27:20.180
get ready as we head on into the idea
of release, control, and validation.

527
00:27:20.180 --> 00:27:22.704
Review these skills,
make sure you feel comfortable with them.

528
00:27:22.704 --> 00:27:27.126
Again, even if you have already done
the ITIL foundation, it's a great time for

529
00:27:27.126 --> 00:27:31.549
you to review that before we start on some
new information that we have to be able to

530
00:27:31.549 --> 00:27:33.850
chew on to get ready for
this exam as well.

531
00:27:33.850 --> 00:27:34.770
And of course,

532
00:27:34.770 --> 00:27:38.950
Terry has also given us a few examples
to where you also see this in real life.

533
00:27:38.950 --> 00:27:43.790
And since this particular exam is focused
in on the idea of practicality and

534
00:27:43.790 --> 00:27:47.210
orientation, and transitioning,
it's a great place

535
00:27:47.210 --> 00:27:51.180
to just start off in the right things
which is always a review of foundations.

536
00:27:51.180 --> 00:27:54.850
Well that's also a great place for
us to end this episode as well.

537
00:27:54.850 --> 00:27:59.142
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

538
00:27:59.142 --> 00:28:00.229
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

539
00:28:00.229 --> 00:28:04.438
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Release, Control, and Validation.

540
00:28:05.954 --> 00:28:11.843
[MUSIC]

541
00:28:11.843 --> 00:28:14.902
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Terry continue with the some the foundational vocabulary and concept to prepare for the Release, Control and Validation. They focus in on RACI, function and service.  The guys describe the use of the RACI matrix and its importance.  They also distinguish processes and services and put into the context of responsibility
episodes.title: Review and Orientation Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:01.220
Welcome back to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.220 --> 00:00:06.653
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.653 --> 00:00:08.445
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.445 --> 00:00:12.668
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.668 --> 00:00:16.100
>> Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.100 --> 00:00:20.910
I'm your host, Ronny Wong, and today we're
taking look at ITIL release, control,

7
00:00:20.910 --> 00:00:22.180
and validation.

8
00:00:22.180 --> 00:00:26.330
We're specifically going to be diving
into, well, a little bit more review.

9
00:00:26.330 --> 00:00:29.310
Making sure that we understand
a bit more vocabulary and

10
00:00:29.310 --> 00:00:33.230
some of the different concepts that we
need to have solidified in our mind before

11
00:00:33.230 --> 00:00:36.720
we move into those different
concepts at the intermediate level.

12
00:00:36.720 --> 00:00:39.570
And here to help us out is gonna be
our subject matter expert himself, Mr.

13
00:00:39.570 --> 00:00:40.300
Terry Decker.

14
00:00:40.300 --> 00:00:41.620
Terry, welcome back to the show.

15
00:00:41.620 --> 00:00:42.670
>> Glad to be back.

16
00:00:42.670 --> 00:00:46.960
And as Ronnie said,
we got just a few more concepts and words,

17
00:00:46.960 --> 00:00:49.750
vocabulary to figure
out before we dive in.

18
00:00:49.750 --> 00:00:54.150
And not too much more to go on
this review, but let's dig in.

19
00:00:54.150 --> 00:00:56.880
First of all, what is a process?

20
00:00:56.880 --> 00:00:59.360
Again, nothing magical
about this definition.

21
00:00:59.360 --> 00:01:01.730
A structured set of activities.

22
00:01:01.730 --> 00:01:06.630
They have a very specific goal in mind,
they give some sort of output to

23
00:01:06.630 --> 00:01:09.880
some sort of stakeholder, and
something gets them started.

24
00:01:09.880 --> 00:01:13.520
We're gonna specifically be talking
about seven different processes

25
00:01:13.520 --> 00:01:17.240
as we dive in to RCV in later episodes.

26
00:01:17.240 --> 00:01:18.060
And basically,

27
00:01:18.060 --> 00:01:23.590
that's the episode outline, is each of
these processes we go through, right?

28
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:26.060
>> Now, Terry,
when we talk about the idea of process,

29
00:01:26.060 --> 00:01:28.540
a lot of us just work through things.

30
00:01:28.540 --> 00:01:31.540
We tend to just kinda go,
okay, here it is.

31
00:01:31.540 --> 00:01:34.720
And we might do the same
thing one way one time,

32
00:01:34.720 --> 00:01:37.230
the second time I might
do it a different way.

33
00:01:37.230 --> 00:01:39.850
And they both seem to
accomplish the same thing.

34
00:01:39.850 --> 00:01:42.660
But when you're talking about
in terms of a real process,

35
00:01:42.660 --> 00:01:46.900
though, you're actually saying that this
kind of needs to happen uniformly, right?

36
00:01:46.900 --> 00:01:47.980
>> Absolutely structured.

37
00:01:47.980 --> 00:01:51.160
A process is defined,
it has specific outputs in mind,

38
00:01:51.160 --> 00:01:53.785
specific stakeholders in mind,
it is repeatable.

39
00:01:53.785 --> 00:01:55.150
Now, certainly,

40
00:01:55.150 --> 00:01:59.170
in the life cycle of a process there's
gonna be different levels of maturity.

41
00:01:59.170 --> 00:02:03.290
And if you go to any given process and
audit it, it might be, well,

42
00:02:03.290 --> 00:02:05.670
let's document it, but
we don't really follow it, right?

43
00:02:05.670 --> 00:02:06.625
You can certainly get that.

44
00:02:06.625 --> 00:02:08.410
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or we follow it, but

45
00:02:08.410 --> 00:02:10.930
we have to kinda go around it this way,
right?

46
00:02:10.930 --> 00:02:12.160
So that always happens.

47
00:02:12.160 --> 00:02:15.380
So a part of process ownership,
which we'll talk a little bit later,

48
00:02:15.380 --> 00:02:18.100
is making sure that the process is fit for
purpose.

49
00:02:18.100 --> 00:02:23.442
So ITIL, effectively, in one regard you
could look at ITIL as a process model,

50
00:02:23.442 --> 00:02:27.826
which is a great segue to the next topic,
is that a process model,

51
00:02:27.826 --> 00:02:31.045
a process doesn't exist in a vacuum.

52
00:02:31.045 --> 00:02:33.065
It has to have controls around it.

53
00:02:33.065 --> 00:02:34.615
It has to have objectives around it.

54
00:02:34.615 --> 00:02:36.735
What are we trying to
do with this process?

55
00:02:36.735 --> 00:02:39.695
What value is it supposed
to be delivering, right?

56
00:02:39.695 --> 00:02:41.889
And then, if you look at
the lower part of this graphic,

57
00:02:41.889 --> 00:02:44.178
you see there's actually
practitioners of the process,

58
00:02:44.178 --> 00:02:46.767
people that know the process and
what it's supposed to be doing.

59
00:02:46.767 --> 00:02:50.892
And in the middle is actually
what it does, the process.

60
00:02:50.892 --> 00:02:54.232
Something gets it started,
it has some sort of output, all right?

61
00:02:54.232 --> 00:02:58.642
But they key takeaway here is
processes don't exist in a vacuum.

62
00:02:58.642 --> 00:03:03.452
And the way this plays out on exam
is it could be in the scenario,

63
00:03:03.452 --> 00:03:07.180
in the exam, they might describe,
you've defined a process, but

64
00:03:07.180 --> 00:03:10.860
it's not really bought into,
people aren't following it, right?

65
00:03:10.860 --> 00:03:14.840
So your point of inquiry is in
why aren't people following it?

66
00:03:14.840 --> 00:03:19.520
Do we need policy to make people do it,
or is it just a broken process and

67
00:03:19.520 --> 00:03:21.220
therefore not effective, right?

68
00:03:21.220 --> 00:03:24.040
So again, as it plays out on a scenario,

69
00:03:24.040 --> 00:03:28.165
you must remember that a process does
not exist on an island by itself.

70
00:03:28.165 --> 00:03:30.220
There's things around it
that make it successful.

71
00:03:30.220 --> 00:03:35.000
Such as policy, such as well trained
people in measurement and audit.

72
00:03:35.000 --> 00:03:37.380
>> Now, Terry, when I take a look
at what you're showing us here,

73
00:03:37.380 --> 00:03:41.400
though, on the left hand side,
it seems to be in pretty big letters here.

74
00:03:41.400 --> 00:03:43.240
You gotta explain what
this means a little bit,

75
00:03:43.240 --> 00:03:46.730
how it can actually expand organizational
and even geographical boundaries.

76
00:03:46.730 --> 00:03:48.160
What are you talking about there?

77
00:03:48.160 --> 00:03:51.290
>> Well,
consider your own process model here.

78
00:03:51.290 --> 00:03:57.920
You have a process by which people
can engage for ITProTV content.

79
00:03:57.920 --> 00:03:59.289
Are there geographic boundaries?

80
00:04:00.330 --> 00:04:01.000
>> Not that we know of.

81
00:04:01.000 --> 00:04:05.100
>> Not geographic constraints, but
there's certainly geographic scope, right?

82
00:04:05.100 --> 00:04:05.630
>> Right.

83
00:04:05.630 --> 00:04:08.250
>> But you need to understand that
geography when you're providing it.

84
00:04:08.250 --> 00:04:12.750
Do you actually serve worldwide,
anywhere there's an Internet connection?

85
00:04:12.750 --> 00:04:13.780
Pretty much anywhere there is.

86
00:04:15.040 --> 00:04:19.080
So your geographic boundaries aren't so
built in, right?

87
00:04:19.080 --> 00:04:20.060
That's for sure.

88
00:04:20.060 --> 00:04:23.880
As part of your service provision,
though, the process of on-boarding

89
00:04:23.880 --> 00:04:27.180
subject matter experts,
you had to deal with my geography.

90
00:04:27.180 --> 00:04:27.770
>> Right.

91
00:04:27.770 --> 00:04:31.130
>> Cuz I don't live here
where ITProTV studios are.

92
00:04:31.130 --> 00:04:33.370
So I had to get here, travel here.

93
00:04:33.370 --> 00:04:36.110
So, part of the process is engaging me.

94
00:04:36.110 --> 00:04:38.463
>> Okay.
>> To make sure that I had accommodations,

95
00:04:38.463 --> 00:04:41.360
to make sure that I was able
to get here on time, etc.

96
00:04:41.360 --> 00:04:46.601
Is part of the process model for
on-boarding subject matter expert.

97
00:04:46.601 --> 00:04:48.800
So, yeah, and
certain organizational boundaries.

98
00:04:48.800 --> 00:04:52.530
I'm not an ITProTV employee.

99
00:04:52.530 --> 00:04:56.760
So there's a process that also is spanning
organizational boundaries as well.

100
00:04:56.760 --> 00:04:59.930
As it relates to an IT service,
you certainly got boundaries of

101
00:04:59.930 --> 00:05:03.660
your customers could be
at geographic locations.

102
00:05:03.660 --> 00:05:07.220
You have suppliers that
are helping you do things, so

103
00:05:07.220 --> 00:05:10.030
you're crossing organizational
boundaries there.

104
00:05:10.030 --> 00:05:14.150
If you're trying to manage a change, which
we'll talk about later on, and to get this

105
00:05:14.150 --> 00:05:17.520
change fully done you need some
development resources and you outsource

106
00:05:17.520 --> 00:05:22.230
the development, obviously you're passing
organizational boundaries there as well.

107
00:05:22.230 --> 00:05:22.970
>> All right, sounds good.

108
00:05:22.970 --> 00:05:27.110
>> Thanks for asking.

109
00:05:27.110 --> 00:05:29.110
Another topic to pick up on.

110
00:05:29.110 --> 00:05:31.060
Another word ITIL uses is function.

111
00:05:31.060 --> 00:05:34.755
So we got processes which
are a structure set of activity.

112
00:05:34.755 --> 00:05:39.050
ITIL describes 26 processes, we're talking
about seven of them in this course.

113
00:05:41.260 --> 00:05:42.795
But they also use the word function.

114
00:05:42.795 --> 00:05:45.200
And function's very specifically used.

115
00:05:45.200 --> 00:05:51.000
It means the group of people that get work
done for the IT service provider, right?

116
00:05:51.000 --> 00:05:53.665
They have special skills and
special tools.

117
00:05:53.665 --> 00:05:59.970
ITIL is really good at distilling
broad concepts into digestible bits.

118
00:05:59.970 --> 00:06:02.487
So they describe four functions,
and only for functions.

119
00:06:02.487 --> 00:06:06.829
The service desk that single point
of contact between the end users and

120
00:06:06.829 --> 00:06:08.309
the service provider.

121
00:06:08.309 --> 00:06:09.754
IT operations.

122
00:06:09.754 --> 00:06:13.386
Those are groups of people
with special skills and

123
00:06:13.386 --> 00:06:18.250
tools that get the day to day
business of IT accomplished, right?

124
00:06:18.250 --> 00:06:20.500
Back ups and restores.

125
00:06:20.500 --> 00:06:25.310
Storage maintenance, printer maintenance,
data centers, fuel generators,

126
00:06:25.310 --> 00:06:27.420
power conditioners, those type of things.

127
00:06:27.420 --> 00:06:29.480
The day to day grind of IT.

128
00:06:29.480 --> 00:06:32.130
And then, technical management and
application management,

129
00:06:32.130 --> 00:06:36.210
those are functions that ITIL
describes as being able to go deep and

130
00:06:36.210 --> 00:06:38.110
wide into their areas of specialty.

131
00:06:38.110 --> 00:06:41.790
They have a lot in common, they just
have different domains of knowledge.

132
00:06:41.790 --> 00:06:43.677
Technical management
is the infrastructure,

133
00:06:43.677 --> 00:06:44.768
the things in the back end.

134
00:06:44.768 --> 00:06:48.430
Servers, databases,
mainframe computers, networks.

135
00:06:50.670 --> 00:06:54.850
Application management are those skill
sets that are closer to the front

136
00:06:54.850 --> 00:06:56.110
near the users.

137
00:06:56.110 --> 00:06:58.490
What applications are being used?

138
00:06:58.490 --> 00:07:01.380
Again, those two functions, technical
management and application management.

139
00:07:01.380 --> 00:07:04.720
While they have different
areas of specialty,

140
00:07:04.720 --> 00:07:09.010
they focus on those areas at a deep and
wide level.

141
00:07:09.010 --> 00:07:11.530
So they can show up at strategic meetings.

142
00:07:11.530 --> 00:07:13.550
They can show up at tactical meetings.

143
00:07:13.550 --> 00:07:16.900
They can make decisions on
whether we should buy it or

144
00:07:16.900 --> 00:07:19.080
externally provide it, right?

145
00:07:19.080 --> 00:07:22.110
They help you make decisions on cost and
risk and value, right?

146
00:07:23.120 --> 00:07:26.560
So IT operations, day to day grind,
technical management,

147
00:07:26.560 --> 00:07:28.520
application management, deep dives.

148
00:07:30.410 --> 00:07:32.510
>> Now, Terry, when you talk
about this idea of functionality,

149
00:07:32.510 --> 00:07:35.900
I was reading the definition here, and I
tend to pick things apart when I probably

150
00:07:35.900 --> 00:07:37.340
shouldn't, but
you'll have to tell me or not.

151
00:07:37.340 --> 00:07:40.180
>> Sure.
>> When you talk about this idea of

152
00:07:40.180 --> 00:07:43.350
people doing it, but also tools.

153
00:07:43.350 --> 00:07:47.282
So, for example, the idea of the service
desk is not really only inclusive of

154
00:07:47.282 --> 00:07:50.076
the person doing it, but
also their technical tools.

155
00:07:50.076 --> 00:07:52.039
Like if they're carrying a laptop around,

156
00:07:52.039 --> 00:07:55.179
that's also part of this function
that we're talking about as well?

157
00:07:55.179 --> 00:07:55.751
>> That's right.

158
00:07:55.751 --> 00:07:57.180
>> Okay.
>> Special skills and tools.

159
00:07:57.180 --> 00:08:00.223
So obviously for
a service desk to be functional, and

160
00:08:00.223 --> 00:08:05.070
I use the word function there, to be
functional as opposed to dysfunctional.

161
00:08:05.070 --> 00:08:07.200
It would need to have
perhaps telephone services,

162
00:08:07.200 --> 00:08:09.360
it needs to have laptops perhaps.

163
00:08:09.360 --> 00:08:13.710
It needs to have a ticketing system,
log these incidents that come in.

164
00:08:13.710 --> 00:08:16.570
Those types of things, so
a means of communication that's outreach.

165
00:08:16.570 --> 00:08:20.390
Maybe the service desk is engaged through
a web interface and not the telephone.

166
00:08:20.390 --> 00:08:22.320
That could be a toolset.

167
00:08:22.320 --> 00:08:25.870
Maybe the service desk is engaged
through chat, various ways.

168
00:08:25.870 --> 00:08:27.910
So exactly, you're pointing to it,

169
00:08:27.910 --> 00:08:30.960
very good Ronnie, is that the service
desk has these people but

170
00:08:30.960 --> 00:08:34.580
it's also maintenance of those tools and
those toolsets that make them successful.

171
00:08:34.580 --> 00:08:36.750
And you could apply that
to any of the functions.

172
00:08:36.750 --> 00:08:40.760
What does a data center technician need
to be successful, those types of things.

173
00:08:40.760 --> 00:08:42.292
Yep, good questions.

174
00:08:42.292 --> 00:08:45.670
All right Terry so now that we've
talked about just briefly the idea of

175
00:08:45.670 --> 00:08:49.370
processes and functions, trying to make
sure that we get our heads wrap around

176
00:08:49.370 --> 00:08:52.160
that as far as review before
we head into the intermediate.

177
00:08:52.160 --> 00:08:55.270
What is another concept that
we need to really focus in on?

178
00:08:55.270 --> 00:08:58.060
>> Well this is another one to showed up
on one of those review questions about

179
00:08:58.060 --> 00:09:02.180
the idea of RACI and you are very good to
come up to those responsible accountable,

180
00:09:02.180 --> 00:09:03.650
consulted, and informed.

181
00:09:03.650 --> 00:09:04.760
And that's what it is.

182
00:09:04.760 --> 00:09:09.630
And you see from the graphic here is that,

183
00:09:09.630 --> 00:09:15.980
a RACI Matrix if you will, allows you the
opportunity to map roles to activities.

184
00:09:15.980 --> 00:09:20.460
And describe varying degrees
of interface with activity.

185
00:09:20.460 --> 00:09:25.600
So accountable, in fact I've seen it
referred to as ARCI instead of RACI.

186
00:09:25.600 --> 00:09:28.660
Because the A is kind of the boss here,
and

187
00:09:28.660 --> 00:09:32.360
A is accountable,
they don't actually do anything.

188
00:09:32.360 --> 00:09:33.700
They just make sure it gets done.

189
00:09:33.700 --> 00:09:37.970
So in this case, the director of
service management is accountable for

190
00:09:37.970 --> 00:09:39.150
activity one.

191
00:09:39.150 --> 00:09:41.080
They happen to be responsible for it too.

192
00:09:41.080 --> 00:09:44.450
If you look a bit later you'll see that
the Director of Service Management

193
00:09:44.450 --> 00:09:46.830
is accountable for activity two.

194
00:09:46.830 --> 00:09:49.840
That would mean that the Director
of Service Management makes sure

195
00:09:49.840 --> 00:09:51.730
activity two gets done.

196
00:09:51.730 --> 00:09:52.710
But they don't actually do it.

197
00:09:53.880 --> 00:09:55.980
So some rules of thumb about the RACI are,

198
00:09:55.980 --> 00:09:59.590
is that you should only have
one accountable person.

199
00:09:59.590 --> 00:10:02.470
I kinda learned this in CPR,
when I took CPR training.

432
00:22:14.470 --> 00:22:17.290
All those will give you at least
a basic review of the vocabulary

433
00:22:17.290 --> 00:22:22.080
that you need to have before we
move on to another episode as well.

434
00:22:22.080 --> 00:22:25.360
But until that point, this is
a great place for us to go ahead and

435
00:22:25.360 --> 00:22:27.020
end this episode then.

436
00:22:27.020 --> 00:22:31.340
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

437
00:22:31.340 --> 00:22:32.460
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

438
00:22:32.460 --> 00:22:37.417
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL: Release, Control and Validation.

439
00:22:39.159 --> 00:22:44.912
[MUSIC]

440
00:22:44.912 --> 00:22:48.314
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Terry introduce the ITIL Service Transition model.  They present a high level overview of service transition.  They guys briefly describe the scope and they discuss the business value of Service Transition.  Also presented by them is the service transition strategy as the guiding factor to this area of study.
episodes.title: Service Transition Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:05.073
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:05.073 --> 00:00:08.233
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.233 --> 00:00:12.396
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.396 --> 00:00:15.710
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.710 --> 00:00:20.370
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
today we're diving back into ITIL release,

6
00:00:20.370 --> 00:00:21.990
control, and validation.

7
00:00:21.990 --> 00:00:26.450
We're specifically going to be addressing
an overview of service transition.

8
00:00:26.450 --> 00:00:29.120
Because it's important that we actually
understand the whole picture that we're

9
00:00:29.120 --> 00:00:30.140
taking a look at.

10
00:00:30.140 --> 00:00:32.170
And then we'll dive into
some of the specifics.

11
00:00:32.170 --> 00:00:35.570
And here to help us to understand that
better is gonna be Mr. Terry Decker.

12
00:00:35.570 --> 00:00:36.800
Terry welcome back to our show.

13
00:00:36.800 --> 00:00:38.100
>> Glad to be here Ronnie, and

14
00:00:38.100 --> 00:00:42.810
as you said we're gonna be looking at
the life cycle stage at large, right?

15
00:00:42.810 --> 00:00:46.560
The bulk of this course is gonna
be diving into the processes,

16
00:00:46.560 --> 00:00:48.510
there's seven specific processes.

17
00:00:48.510 --> 00:00:52.690
But before we do that we wanna remind
everyone just what service transition is

18
00:00:52.690 --> 00:00:55.220
about and what it's trying to
get done as an entire stage.

19
00:00:55.220 --> 00:00:59.480
Because six of these seven
processes exist in this stage.

20
00:00:59.480 --> 00:01:02.180
So again what is transition trying to do?

21
00:01:02.180 --> 00:01:03.960
A service transition
is one of five stages.

22
00:01:03.960 --> 00:01:07.840
You'll remember service strategy,
service design, then service transition.

23
00:01:07.840 --> 00:01:12.110
And service transition is trying
to bring services to life or

24
00:01:12.110 --> 00:01:14.710
to change existing services.

25
00:01:14.710 --> 00:01:16.510
And even retire services.

26
00:01:16.510 --> 00:01:20.060
So service transition is
managing all the activities

27
00:01:20.060 --> 00:01:22.440
that make that stage successful.

28
00:01:22.440 --> 00:01:27.050
And then bringing a service to life and
operations for ongoing quality and

29
00:01:27.050 --> 00:01:28.780
delivery to the customers.

30
00:01:28.780 --> 00:01:31.700
So the primary objective of
service transition is to make

31
00:01:31.700 --> 00:01:35.960
services come to life, plan and manage
the risk, coordinate the resources, and

32
00:01:35.960 --> 00:01:37.309
do so in a repeatable fashion.

33
00:01:38.730 --> 00:01:40.980
So have a look here at the slide here,

34
00:01:40.980 --> 00:01:46.570
the scope of service transition,
is new and change services, right?

35
00:01:46.570 --> 00:01:50.250
It also could be retiring
services as we mentioned, right?

36
00:01:50.250 --> 00:01:53.960
You need to allow for the innovation
while reducing the risk and impact.

37
00:01:53.960 --> 00:01:59.050
Whenever you tweak a service that already
exists, there could be offsetting effects.

38
00:01:59.050 --> 00:02:01.160
Maybe the customers have to be retrained.

39
00:02:01.160 --> 00:02:04.380
They'll want to know, hey, wait a minute,
I thought I went here for that.

40
00:02:04.380 --> 00:02:05.920
And you moved the ball on them.

41
00:02:05.920 --> 00:02:10.420
So managing that change so the customers
are happy throughout the change.

42
00:02:10.420 --> 00:02:14.920
If you're bringing a new service in, you
need to manage that as well, all right?

43
00:02:14.920 --> 00:02:17.312
And of course,
decommissioning your services.

44
00:02:17.312 --> 00:02:23.730
The reason you managed service transition
as a stage and provide high quality here,

45
00:02:23.730 --> 00:02:27.840
is so you can manage change cost
effectively and risk effectively..

46
00:02:27.840 --> 00:02:32.869
You mitigate the risks, you optimize
the risk is a term often used by ITIL.

47
00:02:32.869 --> 00:02:36.626
Meaning some risks are worth taking but
you're going to take them with eyes open,

48
00:02:36.626 --> 00:02:38.760
right, you understand
what those risks are.

49
00:02:38.760 --> 00:02:42.240
Because change in itself means risk.

50
00:02:42.240 --> 00:02:43.900
But you wanna have a positive outcome.

51
00:02:43.900 --> 00:02:46.645
You want to lower the efforts it takes.

52
00:02:46.645 --> 00:02:50.880
While some folks would look at
introducing process as bureaucracy,

53
00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:55.570
you need to get that right balance
of control and effectiveness.

54
00:02:55.570 --> 00:02:58.200
And that's what the business
value is looking for here.

55
00:03:01.000 --> 00:03:06.110
So, the strategy for transition, that is
if the transition strategy is to make

56
00:03:06.110 --> 00:03:11.080
sure that you affect appropriate change
at the right time, at the right cost.

57
00:03:11.080 --> 00:03:13.680
And you mitigate the risks, right?

58
00:03:13.680 --> 00:03:17.030
It kinda depends on the size and nature of
the services how much risk is involved and

59
00:03:17.030 --> 00:03:17.790
how big it is.

60
00:03:19.110 --> 00:03:23.560
Service transition is a big topic for
big changes.

61
00:03:23.560 --> 00:03:25.940
It's also a small topic for

62
00:03:25.940 --> 00:03:29.780
small changes, right, day to day
changes that happen in operations.

63
00:03:31.450 --> 00:03:33.920
Changes of existing
services that are small,

64
00:03:33.920 --> 00:03:36.730
changes to existing services that are big.

65
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:39.890
As an example,
we maintain an email service for

66
00:03:39.890 --> 00:03:41.450
years that the company used to work for.

67
00:03:41.450 --> 00:03:45.940
We went from Lotus Notes to Exchange and
SharePoint.

68
00:03:45.940 --> 00:03:51.330
So whereas Lotus Notes
had the groupware pieces,

69
00:03:51.330 --> 00:03:54.390
the collaboration pieces,
the storage, the sharing.

70
00:03:54.390 --> 00:03:56.400
It also had email and calendaring.

71
00:03:56.400 --> 00:03:59.890
Moving to a Microsoft
environment was a big change.

72
00:03:59.890 --> 00:04:03.410
Now we still had a service called Notes,
Lotus Notes, perhaps.

73
00:04:03.410 --> 00:04:05.450
And then we had a new
service called Exchange.

74
00:04:05.450 --> 00:04:08.020
What you call a service
is not that important.

75
00:04:08.020 --> 00:04:09.748
But it was a big difference, right?

76
00:04:09.748 --> 00:04:12.120
Now some folks say,
well email is just email.

77
00:04:12.120 --> 00:04:15.790
I kind of get that on the email side,
but what about the collaboration side?

78
00:04:15.790 --> 00:04:19.286
SharePoint is certainly a lot
different than Lotus Notes, right?

79
00:04:19.286 --> 00:04:20.520
So that was a big change,

80
00:04:20.520 --> 00:04:23.470
even though we're providing
the same type of functionality.

81
00:04:23.470 --> 00:04:27.148
The same type of utility and we're
gonna promise the same kind of warranty

82
00:04:27.148 --> 00:04:30.910
that's gonna be available 24/7,
high availability.

83
00:04:30.910 --> 00:04:32.390
It was gonna be a big change.

84
00:04:32.390 --> 00:04:36.810
So not only do we have to change our staff
orientation within the service provider,

85
00:04:36.810 --> 00:04:39.250
we had to orient
the business users as well.

86
00:04:39.250 --> 00:04:41.030
So it was a big deal, all right?

87
00:04:41.030 --> 00:04:46.280
Minor changes, we add a utility
to Outlook that allows them to

88
00:04:46.280 --> 00:04:51.050
easily connect to Live Meeting, or
WebEx, or some other utility, right.

89
00:04:51.050 --> 00:04:54.380
That's not as big a change but
it's still something you have to manage.

90
00:04:54.380 --> 00:04:59.228
Service transition is a life cycle
stage that deals with the complexity

91
00:04:59.228 --> 00:05:03.289
of big changes and
the complexity of small changes as well.

92
00:05:03.289 --> 00:05:06.289
>> All right so Terry let's kind of talk
about these three concepts because we kind

93
00:05:06.289 --> 00:05:07.855
of rifled through them pretty quickly.

94
00:05:07.855 --> 00:05:10.140
>> Sure.
>> You talked about the idea of scope and

95
00:05:10.140 --> 00:05:12.680
business value,
as well as the ideal of strategy.

96
00:05:12.680 --> 00:05:15.470
Now, when we start talking
about the idea of scope,

97
00:05:15.470 --> 00:05:18.040
cuz this is,
was a phrase that you had used,

98
00:05:18.040 --> 00:05:20.760
which is something that we might
wanna elaborate on just a little bit.

99
00:05:20.760 --> 00:05:21.567
>> Sure.
>> Coming from me,

100
00:05:21.567 --> 00:05:24.405
since I'm not as smart as most of the guys
that are probably watching this, right?

101
00:05:24.405 --> 00:05:26.559
>> [LAUGH]
>> And most ladies watching this here.

102
00:05:26.559 --> 00:05:30.153
The idea of trying to retire,
I think is what you said,

103
00:05:30.153 --> 00:05:32.276
discontinuation of a service.

104
00:05:32.276 --> 00:05:36.970
Why does that have to be a managed
service transition at all?

105
00:05:36.970 --> 00:05:38.780
Why not just say everybody stop using it?

106
00:05:38.780 --> 00:05:39.620
Why not?

107
00:05:39.620 --> 00:05:41.110
>> Well it's a good point.

108
00:05:41.110 --> 00:05:44.650
First of all just using a facetious
example, I know I've done this.

109
00:05:44.650 --> 00:05:46.890
I'm not sure if they're using this,
let's just turn it off.

110
00:05:46.890 --> 00:05:48.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's just turn it off and

111
00:05:48.490 --> 00:05:49.910
see people are screaming.

112
00:05:49.910 --> 00:05:52.530
So you gotta make sure the customers
are indeed ready for it.

113
00:05:52.530 --> 00:05:55.370
So it's not just telling them,
it's making sure they're ready for it.

114
00:05:55.370 --> 00:06:00.470
So perhaps it was, pick the service, they
were using that service potentially for

115
00:06:00.470 --> 00:06:02.270
some business outcome.

116
00:06:02.270 --> 00:06:03.860
You're taking that service away,

117
00:06:03.860 --> 00:06:06.890
do they still get the business
outcome they're desired?

118
00:06:06.890 --> 00:06:09.040
And also, reuse of capacity.

119
00:06:09.040 --> 00:06:13.400
So if you're taking down a service,
there's components of that service that

120
00:06:13.400 --> 00:06:18.340
were in play, people,
resources, servers, databases.

121
00:06:18.340 --> 00:06:20.800
Can you reuse that effectively?

122
00:06:20.800 --> 00:06:21.360
>> All right.
>> So

123
00:06:21.360 --> 00:06:25.760
you're going to regain some capacity
if you're taking down a service.

124
00:06:25.760 --> 00:06:27.700
How can that capacity be reused?

125
00:06:27.700 --> 00:06:29.620
These are intelligent questions to ask.

126
00:06:29.620 --> 00:06:34.310
So having an intelligent approach to
asking those questions consistently, and

127
00:06:34.310 --> 00:06:36.710
methodically, is what service
transition would provide.

128
00:06:36.710 --> 00:06:39.640
>> You know, the understanding
the scope is something that I find

129
00:06:39.640 --> 00:06:43.310
even in project management
that tends to get out of hand.

130
00:06:43.310 --> 00:06:44.420
When you're talking about that,

131
00:06:44.420 --> 00:06:48.890
I always make an illustration that
project management is like a wedding.

132
00:06:48.890 --> 00:06:52.530
It always begins small, but
it always continues to grow.

133
00:06:52.530 --> 00:06:54.250
You never see it shrinking.

134
00:06:54.250 --> 00:06:56.780
And so the idea of setting a scope
here is that the same idea as

135
00:06:56.780 --> 00:07:01.080
making sure it doesn't go beyond
what we really want it to be?

136
00:07:01.080 --> 00:07:01.800
>> Great example.

137
00:07:02.800 --> 00:07:06.990
When you're defining any process, and
we're gonna be talking about a lot of

138
00:07:06.990 --> 00:07:10.380
these processes, you're gonna make
some decisions along the way.

139
00:07:10.380 --> 00:07:12.205
What is the scope of this process?

140
00:07:12.205 --> 00:07:14.920
So we're talking about service
transition as a stage.

141
00:07:14.920 --> 00:07:16.837
It has scope, as well.

142
00:07:16.837 --> 00:07:21.512
I know some organizations that
consider project-level changes big

143
00:07:21.512 --> 00:07:26.720
enough that they just allow a project
management discipline to handle.

144
00:07:26.720 --> 00:07:27.950
>> Okay.

145
00:07:27.950 --> 00:07:30.420
>> The details, right?

146
00:07:30.420 --> 00:07:35.165
And then day to day operation of change
management is handled by other means.

147
00:07:35.165 --> 00:07:37.050
ITIL call that a change model.

148
00:07:37.050 --> 00:07:38.290
>> Okay.
>> You have a model for

149
00:07:38.290 --> 00:07:40.060
handling the big things and

150
00:07:40.060 --> 00:07:42.830
you have a model handling
the day to day things, right?

151
00:07:42.830 --> 00:07:47.355
So were certainly gonna get the details of
that type of scope analysis later on and

152
00:07:47.355 --> 00:07:49.040
ITIL is very clever at this.

153
00:07:49.040 --> 00:07:54.875
It is not a mandatory type of practice.

154
00:07:54.875 --> 00:07:56.334
ITIL is a best practice.

155
00:07:56.334 --> 00:07:59.134
It is a framework.

156
00:07:59.134 --> 00:08:03.086
So they expect you to adopt And
then adapt it to your reality and

157
00:08:03.086 --> 00:08:05.142
get those cost effectiveness.

158
00:08:05.142 --> 00:08:08.920
So it's not a standard that says,
thou shalt do this.

159
00:08:08.920 --> 00:08:11.760
It is a framework that says,
these are good ideas,

160
00:08:11.760 --> 00:08:14.930
this is proven to work in
a lot of organizations.

161
00:08:14.930 --> 00:08:16.610
You should consider this seriously and

162
00:08:16.610 --> 00:08:19.740
then apply that as it
fits your organization.

163
00:08:19.740 --> 00:08:22.960
>> All right, so Terry, also moving on to
the concept of the idea of business value.

164
00:08:22.960 --> 00:08:26.071
You had mentioned, and
I don't mean to downgrade any product.

165
00:08:26.071 --> 00:08:26.817
[LAUGH] I really don't.

166
00:08:26.817 --> 00:08:29.977
The idea of Lotus Notes,
as well as using Exchange and

167
00:08:29.977 --> 00:08:32.940
maybe Outlook at the same,
something like that.

168
00:08:32.940 --> 00:08:37.838
The business value seems to kinda point
at the idea that we need some metric

169
00:08:37.838 --> 00:08:39.185
that's involved.

170
00:08:39.185 --> 00:08:43.837
So if you were to try to find that,
cuz I look at it and

171
00:08:43.837 --> 00:08:47.360
go, I'm doing this facetiously.

172
00:08:47.360 --> 00:08:49.430
An email, is an email is an email.

173
00:08:49.430 --> 00:08:54.300
Well, I go, I did the same thing in Lotus
Notes that I'm doing in Exchange now.

174
00:08:54.300 --> 00:08:57.430
So where's the metric that
we would put in there

175
00:08:57.430 --> 00:09:00.010
in terms of the service transition and
you say here it is.

176
00:09:00.010 --> 00:09:01.240
>> Yeah, that's good question.

177
00:09:01.240 --> 00:09:02.780
Let me, thanks for asking.

178
00:09:02.780 --> 00:09:04.400
Let me clarify some boundaries here.

179
00:09:05.480 --> 00:09:09.950
As a whole, ITIL wants you to
find a strategy for the service.

180
00:09:09.950 --> 00:09:10.960
>> Right.

181
00:09:10.960 --> 00:09:14.480
>> The context of transition strategy is

182
00:09:14.480 --> 00:09:17.420
how do you wanna position yourself
with these set of processors?

183
00:09:17.420 --> 00:09:19.808
Do you wanna be highly flexible?

184
00:09:19.808 --> 00:09:23.090
>> Okay.
>> Do you want to be more in control?

185
00:09:23.090 --> 00:09:27.414
I know in some environments
that are highly regulated,

186
00:09:27.414 --> 00:09:30.359
they are little bit averse to change.

187
00:09:30.359 --> 00:09:30.883
>> Right.
>> So

188
00:09:30.883 --> 00:09:33.941
you have a model that handles
that kind of risk aversion.

189
00:09:33.941 --> 00:09:34.450
>> Okay.

190
00:09:34.450 --> 00:09:39.406
>> As opposed to high step environments,
move fast, move fast, I need it now.

191
00:09:39.406 --> 00:09:42.229
I understand that the risks
aren't completely mitigated, but

192
00:09:42.229 --> 00:09:43.595
let's move forward, right.

193
00:09:43.595 --> 00:09:47.467
Depending on the environment, you need
to have a transition strategy that fits

194
00:09:47.467 --> 00:09:49.394
the movement of the business, right.

195
00:09:49.394 --> 00:09:50.235
>> Okay.

196
00:09:50.235 --> 00:09:53.434
>> Some businesses are resistant
to change, let's keep it stable,

197
00:09:53.434 --> 00:09:54.700
don't mess with things.

198
00:09:54.700 --> 00:09:57.040
Some businesses wanna move more quickly.

199
00:09:57.040 --> 00:09:59.810
So your strategy for
service transition is to recognize that.

200
00:09:59.810 --> 00:10:00.400
>> Okay.

201
00:10:00.400 --> 00:10:02.880
>> That's what this is context of that.

202
00:10:02.880 --> 00:10:07.710
As it relates to making a decision on
whether it's worthwhile going from Notes

203
00:10:07.710 --> 00:10:11.890
to Exchange, again,
no disparate marks are necessary at all.

204
00:10:11.890 --> 00:10:13.200
I'm making a business case for

205
00:10:13.200 --> 00:10:15.850
that is actually something that
happens up in Service Strategy.

206
00:10:15.850 --> 00:10:16.692
>> Okay.
>> Right,

207
00:10:16.692 --> 00:10:20.106
Service Strategy is going to be
the life cycle stage that hones in

208
00:10:20.106 --> 00:10:24.173
on what's the value proposition of
making this big change to this service.

209
00:10:24.173 --> 00:10:27.243
We have email,
what's the business strategy gonna be?

210
00:10:27.243 --> 00:10:30.470
Are we going to really go spend a lot
of money making this transition?

211
00:10:30.470 --> 00:10:32.520
How we're gonna justify that expense?

212
00:10:32.520 --> 00:10:33.790
That happens upstairs.

213
00:10:33.790 --> 00:10:35.845
I should say, up higher, Service Strategy.

214
00:10:35.845 --> 00:10:36.960
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yep.

215
00:10:36.960 --> 00:10:40.170
>> Yeah.
So in the transition strategy itself then,

216
00:10:40.170 --> 00:10:44.300
is really important that we tend to
follow what the strategy sets out.

217
00:10:44.300 --> 00:10:47.224
Even if we happen to be kind of,
I hate to put it,

218
00:10:47.224 --> 00:10:51.630
at the lower end, at the provisioning
end of things is very important.

219
00:10:51.630 --> 00:10:55.720
It's more important than me just saying,
I don't care about implementing that way.

220
00:10:55.720 --> 00:10:59.790
We need to follow the strategy because
it allows us to do these services and

221
00:10:59.790 --> 00:11:01.380
provide the value that we want, right.

222
00:11:01.380 --> 00:11:01.930
>> Exactly.

223
00:11:01.930 --> 00:11:02.500
>> Okay.

224
00:11:02.500 --> 00:11:06.300
>> So again, coming up with a transition
strategy that fits the business strategy.

225
00:11:06.300 --> 00:11:10.220
Are you a high growth organization that's

00:23:07.510 --> 00:23:10.400
And then we're going to dive
into these seven processes.

465
00:23:10.400 --> 00:23:14.030
Of these seven, one of them happens
to be considered operations,

466
00:23:14.030 --> 00:23:16.930
this is from service operation,
request fulfillment, but

467
00:23:16.930 --> 00:23:19.840
the other six are all from
the service transition stage.

468
00:23:21.590 --> 00:23:25.105
Two of these processes were not addressed
in service foundation, I'm sorry with

469
00:23:25.105 --> 00:23:29.780
ITIL foundation course, that is change
evaluation and Service Validation and

470
00:23:29.780 --> 00:23:34.970
Testing, those two processes will be
brand new to many viewers here, right?

471
00:23:34.970 --> 00:23:37.150
But that's what we're going next.

472
00:23:37.150 --> 00:23:41.964
I would encourage you to consider
some self study, there's some

473
00:23:41.964 --> 00:23:45.500
directed self study, there's some
exercises related to service transition.

474
00:23:45.500 --> 00:23:50.580
I encourage you to go out and reinforce
what you've learned in this episode

475
00:23:50.580 --> 00:23:54.270
by taking a look at those exercises there,
all right.

476
00:23:54.270 --> 00:23:57.340
>> All right, Terry, well that's a lot
of information for us to consider,

477
00:23:57.340 --> 00:24:00.390
so please do heed what
Terry is telling you.

478
00:24:00.390 --> 00:24:02.750
It's not enough just to sit here and
watch.

479
00:24:02.750 --> 00:24:06.670
You do need to take some time and make
sure you understand those processes and

480
00:24:06.670 --> 00:24:08.890
get in there and
understand the vocabulary,

481
00:24:08.890 --> 00:24:11.850
as well as some of the other concepts that
you've learned about in this episode.

482
00:24:11.850 --> 00:24:17.490
As we get ready for the deeper dive
into each Windows 7 areas as well.

483
00:24:17.490 --> 00:24:20.350
But that's a good place for
us to also end this episode then.

484
00:24:20.350 --> 00:24:23.880
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wang.

485
00:24:23.880 --> 00:24:25.320
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

486
00:24:25.320 --> 00:24:30.347
>> Stay tuned right here for more ITIL
release, control, and validation.

487
00:24:30.347 --> 00:24:36.694
[MUSIC]

488
00:24:36.694 --> 00:24:39.598
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Terry introduce the concept of change management.  They emphasize the importance of change management for the company.  This includes not only the culture of the process but the buy in as well as stated by Terry.  The team describes the inputs, principles and values that change management brings to the company and we begin.  They also discuss the process of change requests and the use of a system to manage these changes.  Terry makes sure to emphasize that ITIL is not proscriptive in managing changes but provides a conceptual framework for what needs to be included in it.
episodes.title: Change Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:04.594
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:04.594 --> 00:00:06.903
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.903 --> 00:00:08.285
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.285 --> 00:00:12.800
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.800 --> 00:00:15.742
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.742 --> 00:00:19.813
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today we're
continuing on taking a look at ITIL,

7
00:00:19.813 --> 00:00:22.500
release, control, and validation.

8
00:00:22.500 --> 00:00:26.430
We're specifically entering into
the realm of change management.

9
00:00:26.430 --> 00:00:29.960
And here to help us out are ITIL
expert himself, Mr. Terry Decker.

10
00:00:29.960 --> 00:00:31.210
Terry, welcome back to our show.

11
00:00:31.210 --> 00:00:33.600
>> Glad to be here, Ronnie, and
thanks for setting the table up.

12
00:00:33.600 --> 00:00:35.870
We are definitely gonna head
into change management.

13
00:00:35.870 --> 00:00:40.440
This is the first of seven processes
among the next several episodes.

14
00:00:40.440 --> 00:00:42.000
And let's just dig right in.

15
00:00:42.000 --> 00:00:43.400
>> All right, sounds good.

16
00:00:43.400 --> 00:00:49.242
So Terry, is it really important that we
implement some system in terms change?

17
00:00:49.242 --> 00:00:52.270
Change happens, this is a constant
that we have in our life.

18
00:00:52.270 --> 00:00:56.766
But what it is about change management
that is really the most important element

19
00:00:56.766 --> 00:00:58.520
for a business to get started?

20
00:00:58.520 --> 00:01:01.400
And why is that so
essential that they set that up?

21
00:01:01.400 --> 00:01:07.760
>> Well, change management provides
the process that, in a methodical way,

22
00:01:07.760 --> 00:01:12.590
can evaluate proposed changes to make
sure they're gonna have intended value.

23
00:01:12.590 --> 00:01:16.980
And to follow up to make sure that
intended value is actually realized,

24
00:01:16.980 --> 00:01:19.620
while mitigating risk and disruption.

25
00:01:19.620 --> 00:01:20.754
>> Wow, okay.

26
00:01:20.754 --> 00:01:23.690
>> So
bringing good change in without harm.

27
00:01:23.690 --> 00:01:27.160
>> All right, so when we start to
take a look at that, we've got

28
00:01:27.160 --> 00:01:30.990
different things that we need to make sure
that we do cover, not only for the exam.

29
00:01:30.990 --> 00:01:34.730
But if you haven't been involved in
this idea of a formalized process for

30
00:01:34.730 --> 00:01:37.610
change management,
it might seem a little bit overwhelming.

31
00:01:37.610 --> 00:01:40.170
But Terry's gonna help us to
understand that a bit better.

32
00:01:40.170 --> 00:01:43.968
And maybe make us a little bit more
comfortable with that concept of change

33
00:01:43.968 --> 00:01:44.710
management.

34
00:01:44.710 --> 00:01:47.866
Terry, you're saying that this is one
of the larger sections that we're gonna

35
00:01:47.866 --> 00:01:48.840
be covering.

36
00:01:48.840 --> 00:01:52.270
So we do need to make sure
that we begin correctly.

37
00:01:52.270 --> 00:01:54.120
So Terry, where are we gonna start?

38
00:01:54.120 --> 00:01:56.590
>> Well, let's just have a look at
the context change management's in.

39
00:01:56.590 --> 00:01:58.340
If you look at the slide here,

40
00:01:58.340 --> 00:02:03.090
change management is one of the seven
processes we're going to be discussing.

41
00:02:03.090 --> 00:02:07.315
And change management is
the authoritative process.

42
00:02:07.315 --> 00:02:10.834
It's the one that grants permissions,
does review,

43
00:02:10.834 --> 00:02:15.500
does triage of value and risk before
actually engaging in any planning,

44
00:02:15.500 --> 00:02:19.573
building, developing or testing,
and those sort of things.

45
00:02:19.573 --> 00:02:21.280
You could look at the rest of them.

46
00:02:21.280 --> 00:02:24.290
Service validation testing,
release and deployment management,

47
00:02:24.290 --> 00:02:28.350
request fulfillment, change evaluation
are all part of the puzzle.

48
00:02:28.350 --> 00:02:31.040
But change management is
actually the authoritative one,

49
00:02:31.040 --> 00:02:33.070
the one that does the triage.

50
00:02:33.070 --> 00:02:39.651
And the one that shepherds these
changes through the process, okay?

51
00:02:39.651 --> 00:02:42.586
>> All right, so as we look for
the overall purpose of this,

52
00:02:42.586 --> 00:02:46.810
you're gonna actually help us by showing
us the overall official term that we're

53
00:02:46.810 --> 00:02:48.350
really looking for.

54
00:02:48.350 --> 00:02:50.820
And then help us understand what
terminology that we need to

55
00:02:50.820 --> 00:02:51.350
really focus on.

56
00:02:51.350 --> 00:02:54.530
>> Well, if you look at the purpose here,
you say, to control, right?

57
00:02:54.530 --> 00:02:56.050
So that's what it's about.

58
00:02:56.050 --> 00:02:58.840
Some folks might look at the word
control and see bureaucracy.

59
00:02:58.840 --> 00:03:01.440
We'll certainly try to evaluate
the difference between control and

60
00:03:01.440 --> 00:03:05.430
bureaucracy as we go through this process.

61
00:03:05.430 --> 00:03:07.520
It's for the life cycle of all changes,

62
00:03:07.520 --> 00:03:12.030
any changes coming to the service,
including the brand new service.

63
00:03:12.030 --> 00:03:14.560
You gotta be responsive to those requests.

64
00:03:14.560 --> 00:03:15.750
Record, evaluate,

65
00:03:15.750 --> 00:03:19.710
keep good records, know where you've been
and where you're going at all times.

66
00:03:19.710 --> 00:03:26.370
And change management is this process
that governs the recording and response.

67
00:03:26.370 --> 00:03:30.480
>> All right, now Terry, before we move on
from that point there, when you start to

68
00:03:30.480 --> 00:03:33.690
take a look, there are a couple of terms
on there that we wanted to point out.

69
00:03:33.690 --> 00:03:37.392
Sometimes I can't define them all,
but we had a couple of acronyms there.

70
00:03:37.392 --> 00:03:41.070
CMS and CI, so
let's talk about those two for a moment.

71
00:03:41.070 --> 00:03:42.870
>> Thanks for pointing those out, Ronnie.

72
00:03:42.870 --> 00:03:44.850
CI is a configuration item.

73
00:03:44.850 --> 00:03:47.700
That's anything you want to
keep under change control.

74
00:03:47.700 --> 00:03:52.122
It could be a piece of technology,
an application, a set of source code.

75
00:03:52.122 --> 00:03:58.810
It could be a document, a processed
document, a service level agreement.

76
00:03:58.810 --> 00:04:04.960
So anything that you decided is
important for you to manage a service.

77
00:04:04.960 --> 00:04:09.870
And you want to keep changes for
that item under control would be a CI.

78
00:04:09.870 --> 00:04:14.671
And those CIs are governed by a process
we'll talk about later called service

79
00:04:14.671 --> 00:04:16.510
asset and configuration management.

80
00:04:16.510 --> 00:04:19.920
And those are stored in a configuration
management system, a CMS.

81
00:04:19.920 --> 00:04:21.260
So thanks for pointing it out.

82
00:04:21.260 --> 00:04:24.380
You would've gotten that
in a foundation course.

83
00:04:24.380 --> 00:04:28.200
And it's good to do the acronym checks
every time, so I appreciate that, Ronnie.

84
00:04:28.200 --> 00:04:32.690
>> All right, so when we start to
then continue on with this idea and

85
00:04:32.690 --> 00:04:37.500
understanding, we wanna also understand
the scope of change management, as well.

86
00:04:37.500 --> 00:04:39.330
So Terry,
when we start talking about a scope,

87
00:04:39.330 --> 00:04:43.770
help us to define this idea of
what our limitations are gonna be.

88
00:04:43.770 --> 00:04:46.860
>> You'll recall from another
episode where I described it,

89
00:04:46.860 --> 00:04:49.830
service transition as a whole,
as the entire stage,

90
00:04:49.830 --> 00:04:53.630
would be involved in big things as well
as the day-to-day things, minor things.

91
00:04:53.630 --> 00:04:56.859
So change management has that scope,
big and small.

92
00:04:56.859 --> 00:04:59.567
And it gets at the very
detailed level of managing

93
00:04:59.567 --> 00:05:02.420
individual configuration items, CIs.

94
00:05:02.420 --> 00:05:07.000
So if you want to change a policy,
you could consider that a CI.

95
00:05:07.000 --> 00:05:10.850
And make sure it follows
a change control process.

96
00:05:10.850 --> 00:05:15.780
If you want to manage the changes
to a server, to a database and

97
00:05:15.780 --> 00:05:18.580
keep them under control,
then those would be CIs.

98
00:05:18.580 --> 00:05:21.640
The database, the server would
be considered CIs, as well.

99
00:05:21.640 --> 00:05:24.810
So not only does it get down to
the detailed level of components,

100
00:05:24.810 --> 00:05:29.430
it gets down to detailed level of other
types of assets, configuration items,

101
00:05:29.430 --> 00:05:32.570
such as documents, processes, etc.

102
00:05:32.570 --> 00:05:35.260
>> All right, Terry, but
there does come a time

103
00:05:35.260 --> 00:05:39.310
in which we're not really describing
the idea of change management anymore.

104
00:05:39.310 --> 00:05:42.700
We're just taking a look at
things that are more operational,

105
00:05:42.700 --> 00:05:45.440
things that we might not
be really concerned with.

106
00:05:45.440 --> 00:05:48.868
So we don't wanna break change management
all the way down to something like

107
00:05:48.868 --> 00:05:49.820
repairing a printer, do we?

108
00:05:49.820 --> 00:05:51.570
>> Probably not, that's a good example.

109
00:05:51.570 --> 00:05:55.329
There could be activities on
a day-to-day basis you might

110
00:05:55.329 --> 00:05:58.270
not want to put under
a strict change control.

111
00:05:58.270 --> 00:06:01.907
Giving someone access to a server,
adding them to Active Directory so

112
00:06:01.907 --> 00:06:03.930
you can have access to things.

113
00:06:03.930 --> 00:06:05.850
Some things just need to move along.

114
00:06:05.850 --> 00:06:10.210
It's not saying there's not a process
in place that has not been reviewed.

115
00:06:10.210 --> 00:06:13.210
It's just not something that has
to go through a rigorous process.

116
00:06:13.210 --> 00:06:14.720
That is the challenge
of change management.

117
00:06:14.720 --> 00:06:18.533
Getting that balance of control and
speed that is necessary,

118
00:06:18.533 --> 00:06:22.505
depending on what the CI is and
the criticality of it is, right?

119
00:06:25.098 --> 00:06:28.056
>> All right, so let's talk
about this terms of the overall,

120
00:06:28.056 --> 00:06:32.258
entire service life cycle, again, helping
us to understand things that might be in

121
00:06:32.258 --> 00:06:34.440
scope and might be out of scope then.

122
00:06:34.440 --> 00:06:35.689
>> Yeah, very good.

123
00:06:35.689 --> 00:06:38.738
One way to consider this is that some
changes have a strategic nature,

124
00:06:38.738 --> 00:06:42.160
some of them have a tactical nature, and
some may have an operational nature.

125
00:06:43.420 --> 00:06:47.290
Strategic assets are the services,
themselves.

126
00:06:47.290 --> 00:06:49.180
It would be a strategic decision,
for instance,

127
00:06:49.180 --> 00:06:53.208
as we've talked about in earlier episodes,
if you wanted to update or

128
00:06:53.208 --> 00:06:56.750
change your email service
from Lotus Notes to Exchange.

129
00:06:56.750 --> 00:06:58.175
That's a big deal, right?

130
00:06:58.175 --> 00:07:00.013
That's a strategic direction.

131
00:07:00.013 --> 00:07:01.990
Change management needs to be there for
that.

132
00:07:01.990 --> 00:07:04.809
A more tactical one might be
where you're going to add some

133
00:07:04.809 --> 00:07:06.370
functionality to SharePoint.

134
00:07:06.370 --> 00:07:10.670
It's already existing, people are using
it as their service for collaboration.

135
00:07:10.670 --> 00:07:12.060
But you're going to tweak it somehow.

136
00:07:12.060 --> 00:07:14.020
That could be a tactical-level change,

137
00:07:14.020 --> 00:07:16.740
where you're gonna add
some value to the service.

138
00:07:16.740 --> 00:07:21.360
And then operationally speaking, the toner
cartridge changes, the user access things.

139
00:07:21.360 --> 00:07:26.200
Those types of changes on an operational
level also need to be managed and

140
00:07:26.200 --> 00:07:27.250
understood.

141
00:07:27.250 --> 00:07:28.780
So change management does operate.

142
00:07:28.780 --> 00:07:30.780
The big level, the small level, and

143
00:07:30.780 --> 00:07:33.630
we could break it down to strategic,
tactical, and operational.

144
00:07:33.630 --> 00:07:37.410
>> All right, now when we start to
take a look at this idea, again,

145
00:07:37.410 --> 00:07:42.030
of trying to say what is actually covered,
we normally have to start off with,

146
00:07:42.030 --> 00:07:46.458
what I'm taking a look at here,
about baselined types of service assets.

147
00:07:46.458 --> 00:07:48.724
And so when we start to look at that,

148
00:07:48.724 --> 00:07:53.045
let's make sure that we understand
that as we move on through here.

149
00:07:53.045 --> 00:07:56.293
>> Baselined just simply means
you know what you have now.

150
00:07:56.293 --> 00:08:01.838
So in Configuration management you
understand how many servers you have.

151
00:08:01.838 --> 00:08:05.352
So if you have 300
servers at patch level Z.

152
00:08:05.352 --> 00:08:06.454
>> Okay.
>> And you need to given

153
00:08:06.454 --> 00:08:09.032
them to patch level,
I should have picked a different letter.

154
00:08:09.032 --> 00:08:11.060
>> AA.
>> Yeah, AA is right.

155
00:08:11.060 --> 00:08:12.810
You wanna get them to patch level AA.

156
00:08:12.810 --> 00:08:15.540
Well, you need to know the baseline
before you manage that change.

157
00:08:16.560 --> 00:08:20.300
So the baseline could be we
have 300 at this patch level,

158
00:08:20.300 --> 00:08:25.860
therefore we need two weeks to get these
all updated to the next patch level.

159
00:08:25.860 --> 00:08:29.880
So that's an idea of where you consider
what your baseline is, where are you now.

160
00:08:29.880 --> 00:08:33.380
It also shows version numbers in software.

161
00:08:33.380 --> 00:08:36.590
If your at version 1.3,
you become version 1.4.

162
00:08:36.590 --> 00:08:39.440
That 1.3 was a baseline at some time.

163
00:08:39.440 --> 00:08:41.200
And 1.4, of course,
is a different baseline.

164
00:08:41.200 --> 00:08:44.299
So you can almost look at
it as version numbers, but

165
00:08:44.299 --> 00:08:47.039
it just really simply
means where are we now,

166
00:08:47.039 --> 00:08:51.093
what is our concurrent status of this CI,
or whatever it might be.

167
00:08:51.093 --> 00:08:55.153
>> So why is it so important that we note
the difference between even the versions,

168
00:08:55.153 --> 00:08:57.770
sometime we can note it
because of functionality.

169
00:08:57.770 --> 00:09:01.170
But in change management what's
the purpose of us saying hey,

170
00:09:01.170 --> 00:09:03.330
here's what it was versus
here's where it is?

171
00:09:03.330 --> 00:09:06.570
What are some of the things that
we're trying to do when we say

172
00:09:06.570 --> 00:09:08.460
here's why we need to manage this change?

173
00:09:08.460 --> 00:09:11.290
Why is it important that I
note something like that?

174
00:09:11.290 --> 00:09:12.610
>> We have bad memories.

175
00:09:12.610 --> 00:09:13.950
>> Okay.
>> Documenting change

176
00:09:15.030 --> 00:09:18.560
is an important aspect of just
having institutional memory.

177
00:09:18.560 --> 00:09:22.790
So whether you're changing a service
level agreement, which is a document,

178
00:09:22.790 --> 00:09:25.210
or changing a version of software,
upgrading it,

179
00:09:25.210 --> 00:09:28.670
or patching a server,
getting it to a different patch level.

180
00:09:28.670 --> 00:09:32.950
Having records of what we've done is
important because we have a bad memories.

181
00:09:32.950 --> 00:09:37.540
So, if you say we changed that service
level just last month, didn't we?

182
00:09:37.540 --> 00:09:39.340
I don't know, let me look,
there you have it,

183
00:09:39.340 --> 00:09:41.599
you have a record of it that we
did change it just last month.

184
00:09:41.599 --> 00:09:43.500
And you understand where you were before.

185
00:09:43.500 --> 00:09:46.620
So it's in keeping in baseline
you know what you had.

186
00:09:46.620 --> 00:09:47.232
And of course,

187
00:09:47.232 --> 00:09:50.117
the baseline changes because your
moving through your change process.

188
00:09:50.117 --> 00:09:54.370
>> Yeah, Terry, and personally as
I've helped out organizations to give

189
00:09:54.370 --> 00:09:58.829
you an example of where change wasn't
really kept as far as the records go and

190
00:09:58.829 --> 00:10:03.569
where really did hurt us is that we had
some terminal servers that were set-up for

191
00:10:03.569 --> 00:10:05.200
some Thin clients.

192
00:10:05.200 --> 00:10:09.570
And one day we came in and we're using
dual monitors and everybody connected in

193
00:10:09.570 --> 00:10:13.210
and that actually stretched the entire
screen across both of those monitors.

194
00:10:13.210 --> 00:10:16.180
And we didn't know exactly
what had occurred,

195
00:10:16.180 --> 00:10:18.940
and we couldn't figure out why
it was actually doing that.

196
00:10:18.940 --> 00:10:19.590
And so

197
00:10:19.590 --> 00:10:23.700
finally we had to troubleshoot everything
else down on those terminal servers.

198
00:10:23.700 --> 00:10:25.200
We knew it wasn't the Thin clients.

199
00:10:25.200 --> 00:10:29.870
But it came down to finally the idea
