00:21:52.178 --> 00:21:56.767
It makes sure it's evaluated, it makes
sure that it's planned accordingly,

432
00:21:56.767 --> 00:22:00.751
it makes sure it's tested appropriately,
deployed on time, etc.

433
00:22:00.751 --> 00:22:02.280
It is accountable.

434
00:22:02.280 --> 00:22:04.820
Release management is
actually responsible.

435
00:22:04.820 --> 00:22:07.370
Release management does the planning,
does the building and

436
00:22:07.370 --> 00:22:11.940
testing, does the deployment and
follows up with some review and closure.

437
00:22:11.940 --> 00:22:15.980
So, critical to change management
is having a responsible arm, right,

438
00:22:15.980 --> 00:22:18.050
not just the authoritative arm.

439
00:22:18.050 --> 00:22:20.590
And release management is
that responsible element.

440
00:22:22.035 --> 00:22:24.660
SACM, as I call it,
service asset configuration management,

441
00:22:24.660 --> 00:22:27.540
SACM, SACM is fundamental and

442
00:22:27.540 --> 00:22:31.430
it defines all your components,
and how they relate to each other.

443
00:22:31.430 --> 00:22:36.200
So, before you do a change,
you might look to SACM as a process

444
00:22:36.200 --> 00:22:39.620
to make sure that the items that
are there are under control, right?

445
00:22:39.620 --> 00:22:43.050
SACM is identifying
which CIs we care about.

446
00:22:43.050 --> 00:22:47.050
Change management is controlling
the changes on those CIs we care about.

447
00:22:47.050 --> 00:22:50.400
>> All right, so it sounds like that we're
ready to start talking about some of

448
00:22:50.400 --> 00:22:53.390
the aspects of designing for
change management.

449
00:22:53.390 --> 00:22:57.451
What are some of the considerations or
inputs that we really need when we start

450
00:22:57.451 --> 00:23:00.143
this process of designing for
change management?

451
00:23:00.143 --> 00:23:03.124
>> So, reminding you that
service change management

452
00:23:03.124 --> 00:23:06.115
is not identical to
solutions change management.

453
00:23:06.115 --> 00:23:07.420
>> Okay.
>> Certainly if you're managing

454
00:23:07.420 --> 00:23:08.950
technology, there's disciplines for

455
00:23:08.950 --> 00:23:11.530
managing technology and
it does include that.

456
00:23:11.530 --> 00:23:13.069
But it goes beyond just technology.

457
00:23:14.200 --> 00:23:20.160
Service change includes things such
as policy, process, engagements

458
00:23:20.160 --> 00:23:23.600
with the customer how you engage with
a customer those types of things.

459
00:23:23.600 --> 00:23:26.560
So, since it goes beyond just technology,

460
00:23:26.560 --> 00:23:29.450
you could get inputs from
all over the place, right?

461
00:23:29.450 --> 00:23:31.780
Not just the technology triggers.

462
00:23:31.780 --> 00:23:33.260
Certainly, from technology vantage point.

463
00:23:33.260 --> 00:23:35.650
The vendor may call and say,
you should do this hot fix.

464
00:23:36.880 --> 00:23:38.970
A user may ring the service desk.

465
00:23:38.970 --> 00:23:43.600
Or 70 users may ring the service desk and
say, I can't find the submit button.

466
00:23:43.600 --> 00:23:45.265
What happened to that button, right?

467
00:23:45.265 --> 00:23:45.985
Those kind of things.

468
00:23:45.985 --> 00:23:50.225
So, it can be technical, certainly can be,
but it also could be process related.

469
00:23:50.225 --> 00:23:54.778
You recall earlier when I talked about
a service coming to me that had a 100

470
00:23:54.778 --> 00:23:57.282
changes a day, I need to tweek a process.

471
00:23:57.282 --> 00:23:59.190
And I needed to change my actual process.

472
00:24:00.250 --> 00:24:02.115
That is under the scope of
change management as well.

473
00:24:02.115 --> 00:24:06.982
So that trigger came from a customer
need that needed to have that much churn

474
00:24:06.982 --> 00:24:09.080
in change management, right?

475
00:24:10.260 --> 00:24:14.240
So the inputs to change management,
how you're going to strategize for

476
00:24:14.240 --> 00:24:19.190
change management are gonna be influenced
by how fast, how much control, and

477
00:24:19.190 --> 00:24:20.840
how complex your environments are.

478
00:24:20.840 --> 00:24:23.000
And what you decide is in scope.

479
00:24:23.000 --> 00:24:26.540
>> Now, Terry,
if my organization let's say,

480
00:24:26.540 --> 00:24:32.240
may have some process that
has legal requirements on it,

481
00:24:32.240 --> 00:24:36.310
do I need to consider that also in
part of the change management itself?

482
00:24:36.310 --> 00:24:39.700
Is there a particular regulation
that I may have to follow?

483
00:24:39.700 --> 00:24:40.480
So, I'm not asking for

484
00:24:40.480 --> 00:24:44.470
specific regulation but is that something
I need to consider if that happens?

485
00:24:44.470 --> 00:24:45.900
>> Absolutely.

486
00:24:45.900 --> 00:24:50.164
Imagine how hospitals are regulated for
an instance and

487
00:24:50.164 --> 00:24:56.253
manage the IT solution that is monitoring
the heart rate of patients in the ICU.

488
00:24:56.253 --> 00:24:57.640
>> Right.
>> Right?

489
00:24:57.640 --> 00:24:58.602
There's probably some critical

490
00:24:58.602 --> 00:24:59.400
regulations-
>> [LAUGH]

491
00:24:59.400 --> 00:25:01.140
>> Regarding how you control

492
00:25:01.140 --> 00:25:02.330
those systems, right?

493
00:25:02.330 --> 00:25:03.500
They go through a lot of testing.

494
00:25:03.500 --> 00:25:06.100
They're probably redundant,
those kind of things.

495
00:25:06.100 --> 00:25:08.120
So if you go about changing those systems,

496
00:25:09.270 --> 00:25:11.000
say you're the manufacturer
of those systems.

497
00:25:11.000 --> 00:25:14.920
Then you're going to be involved
in necessary documentation,

498
00:25:14.920 --> 00:25:16.795
proving you tested your profiles and
things.

499
00:25:16.795 --> 00:25:20.896
I worked in the pharmaceutical
industry for many years and

500
00:25:20.896 --> 00:25:23.993
there were some systems
that we operated and

501
00:25:23.993 --> 00:25:29.616
services we operated that we close
related to federally regulated processes.

502
00:25:29.616 --> 00:25:33.790
So if we wanna change any of that
services we had to show control.

503
00:25:33.790 --> 00:25:34.300
>> Right.

504
00:25:34.300 --> 00:25:38.870
>> So change management can be that lever
that shows you have things under control,

505
00:25:38.870 --> 00:25:41.950
that's how that kinda plays out,
all right.

506
00:25:41.950 --> 00:25:46.410
>> All right, then now the other thing
that I also wanted to ask about as well,

507
00:25:46.410 --> 00:25:48.620
is that even though we can
implement change management,

508
00:25:48.620 --> 00:25:52.870
it doesn't necessarily mean that people
have to do it the way that we say so.

509
00:25:52.870 --> 00:25:55.010
What if they go,
I know that this is what Ronnie said,

510
00:25:55.010 --> 00:25:57.110
but I'm going to do it my way.

511
00:25:57.110 --> 00:25:58.700
Do we have to worry
about things like that?

512
00:25:58.700 --> 00:26:02.680
And there's probably ways that we
can ensure that we don't allow for

513
00:26:02.680 --> 00:26:04.060
unauthorized changes, right?

514
00:26:04.060 --> 00:26:06.230
>> Well there's two things
related to unauthorized change.

515
00:26:06.230 --> 00:26:08.539
One, you have to build the culture
that we're not going to do it.

516
00:26:09.650 --> 00:26:11.030
Back that with policy.

517
00:26:11.030 --> 00:26:12.360
>> Right.
>> Which is even separate from

518
00:26:12.360 --> 00:26:13.940
the process, right?

519
00:26:13.940 --> 00:26:17.190
And make sure the process is fit for
purpose, right?

520
00:26:17.190 --> 00:26:20.320
A lot of people circumvent the process
because they find it's not fit for

521
00:26:20.320 --> 00:26:21.200
purpose, right?

522
00:26:21.200 --> 00:26:25.410
So make sure, so
another thing is to audit, right?

523
00:26:25.410 --> 00:26:30.970
And if you've got policy driving it,
the risk and reward factors.

524
00:26:30.970 --> 00:26:34.300
If there is a policy that says
thou shalt not do and you do,

525
00:26:34.300 --> 00:26:36.680
then there should be some
consequences to it, right?

526
00:26:36.680 --> 00:26:38.730
If it's discovered,
right that sort of thing.

527
00:26:38.730 --> 00:26:42.860
>> Yeah I found out that what happened at
one particular place I was doing a little

528
00:26:42.860 --> 00:26:46.380
bit of consulting on is that when we
said here is what needs to be done and

529
00:26:46.380 --> 00:26:48.740
then they showed
the process of the change.

530
00:26:48.740 --> 00:26:49.970
It was just complex.

531
00:26:49.970 --> 00:26:52.050
It took like 25 changes.

532
00:26:52.050 --> 00:26:54.590
When I said, why don't you all
just do this and this instead?

533
00:26:54.590 --> 00:26:56.230
And he's like, no, no,
this is what our process is.

534
00:26:56.230 --> 00:26:59.146
So I said, I don't want to mess
with your change of management,

535
00:26:59.146 --> 00:27:01.360
because somebody did it
on purpose that way, and

536
00:27:01.360 --> 00:27:04.988
it could be that certain things have to
happen as they come, a procedural step.

537
00:27:04.988 --> 00:27:08.980
Or it's like the ball hitting the Coke
bottle, which hits the spoon,

538
00:27:08.980 --> 00:27:10.095
which does that.

539
00:27:10.095 --> 00:27:14.185
And so I wasn't trying to
undermine that strategy, but

540
00:27:14.185 --> 00:27:17.585
I just didn't understand
that aspect of doing that.

541
00:27:17.585 --> 00:27:21.735
And so I tried by accident to implement
an unauthorized change that way.

542
00:27:21.735 --> 00:27:23.165
And I probably shouldn't have done that.

543
00:27:23.165 --> 00:27:26.960
But you can kinda see where you
really don't understand that but

544
00:27:26.960 --> 00:27:28.780
somebody may have a procedure to it.

545
00:27:28.780 --> 00:27:31.300
And having that change in management in
place somebody can come along and go,

546
00:27:31.300 --> 00:27:34.735
no Ronnie, this is why we do it this way,
and this is effective.

547
00:27:34.735 --> 00:27:37.210
>> That's right, and it needs to
effective, that's just it, Ronnie,

548
00:27:37.210 --> 00:27:38.100
it needs to be effective.

549
00:27:38.100 --> 00:27:42.110
It's incumbent on the process owner to
make sure that the process is actually fit

550
00:27:42.110 --> 00:27:43.200
for purpose.

551
00:27:43.200 --> 00:27:48.600
And you kind of alluded to an aspect
where this looks like one change,

552
00:27:48.600 --> 00:27:50.230
not 25, why did you call it 25 changes?

553
00:27:50.230 --> 00:27:52.400
That's something change
management also needs to govern.

554
00:27:52.400 --> 00:27:54.540
What are we gonna call a release unit?

555
00:27:54.540 --> 00:27:56.400
Is it this entire service?

556
00:27:56.400 --> 00:27:59.460
Anything affecting this service is
considered a change for this service.

557
00:27:59.460 --> 00:28:05.652
Or do you consider the one change or
one big change?

558
00:28:05.652 --> 00:28:09.821
>> All right so now that we have
an idea of what can happen and

559
00:28:09.821 --> 00:28:13.726
some of the inputs that we
need on designing change,

560
00:28:13.726 --> 00:28:18.518
the key comes in then is when
somebody requests a change as well,

561
00:28:18.518 --> 00:28:21.480
and they way that we normally get them.

562
00:28:21.480 --> 00:28:26.800
Working for different sized organizations,
I know that it's run the gamut for me.

563
00:28:26.800 --> 00:28:30.020
Whereas sometimes like here at ITProTV,
it's simple.

564
00:28:30.020 --> 00:28:34.340
There's really not,
everybody that pretty much is on ITProTV,

565
00:28:34.340 --> 00:28:37.020
we kind of are just emailed
here is what needs to be done.

566
00:28:37.020 --> 00:28:38.980
And then we make sure we document it down.

567
00:28:38.980 --> 00:28:42.180
But in a larger organization there was a
ticketing system and something like that.

568
00:28:42.180 --> 00:28:45.170
So let's talk about that idea
of requesting changes and

569
00:28:45.170 --> 00:28:48.290
why that's an important part
of even change management.

570
00:28:48.290 --> 00:28:49.910
>> Very good,
I think that's a great example.

571
00:28:49.910 --> 00:28:53.540
As you mentioned, smaller organizations
don't need to necessarily have such formal

572
00:28:53.540 --> 00:28:54.310
things in place.

573
00:28:54.310 --> 00:28:58.740
It can be communications through email and
then something eventually becomes real and

574
00:28:58.740 --> 00:29:00.910
actionable, that's totally legitimate.

575
00:29:00.910 --> 00:29:04.970
Larger organizations probably need
a bit more defined processes and

576
00:29:04.970 --> 00:29:06.940
points of input, right.

577
00:29:06.940 --> 00:29:10.160
And it depends, and again iTel is
not prescriptive in this regard,

578
00:29:10.160 --> 00:29:14.830
iTel will suggest you adapt these
principles to your reality to

579
00:29:14.830 --> 00:29:19.200
organization, and try to stay out of the
way by providing the same kind of control.

580
00:29:19.200 --> 00:29:24.682
So, again we said before is it a big
thing, is it a small thing, right?

581
00:29:24.682 --> 00:29:28.091
Adding a widget to a SharePoint
can be very disruptive, so

582
00:29:28.091 --> 00:29:32.140
it should be tested because widgets
can do harm as well, right.

583
00:29:32.140 --> 00:29:34.000
So you probably wanna pause on that.

584
00:29:34.000 --> 00:29:38.050
Changing the standard template
from the shade of orange to

585
00:29:38.050 --> 00:29:39.910
a different shade of orange.

586
00:29:39.910 --> 00:29:41.540
Not as impactful, right?

587
00:29:41.540 --> 00:29:43.590
So understanding the differences there.

588
00:29:43.590 --> 00:29:47.620
And of course replacing Lotus Notes
with SharePoint is huge, right?

589
00:29:47.620 --> 00:29:49.540
And all points in between.

590
00:29:49.540 --> 00:29:53.600
So understanding that changes have
varying degrees of complexity and

591
00:29:53.600 --> 00:29:57.360
adapting your change models to
that reality is what's important.

592
00:29:57.360 --> 00:30:00.670
So does that mean that every
change starts off as a project?

593
00:30:00.670 --> 00:30:01.760
Absolutely not.

594
00:30:01.760 --> 00:30:04.230
Are some changes of that scope?

595
00:30:04.230 --> 00:30:06.090
Absolutely, they could be right?

596
00:30:06.090 --> 00:30:10.320
>> So Terry in the idea of requesting for
change regardless of whether we're talking

597
00:30:10.320 --> 00:30:14.320
about small or large, there is supposed
to be some type of formal way to do it.

598
00:30:14.320 --> 00:30:18.154
It's not just walk by the hall and go,
Terry, do you mind changing this for me?

599
00:30:18.154 --> 00:30:22.552
And then me walking on and you walking on,
and 20 minutes later you forget, and

600
00:30:22.552 --> 00:30:24.410
35 minutes later, I forget.

601
00:30:24.410 --> 00:30:29.140
And then later on when a problem happens,
now I'm like, that's right.

602
00:30:29.140 --> 00:30:32.400
I know I told Terry in
the hallway to make that change.

603
00:30:32.400 --> 00:30:34.300
And I come back to Terry and Terry goes?

604
00:30:34.300 --> 00:30:34.910
What?

605
00:30:34.910 --> 00:30:36.090
>> Exactly.

606
00:30:36.090 --> 00:30:38.860
So when you talk about keeping
records in change management,

607
00:30:38.860 --> 00:30:40.910
you're talking about that initiation too.

608
00:30:40.910 --> 00:30:42.640
When do we start the change?

609
00:30:42.640 --> 00:30:45.450
So is a water cooler
conversation sufficient?

610
00:30:45.450 --> 00:30:45.950
No, it's not.

611
00:30:45.950 --> 00:30:49.550
There's going to be some
official record of the request.

612
00:30:49.550 --> 00:30:51.930
And that's also going to be stored,
tucked away,

613
00:30:51.930 --> 00:30:55.220
into the CMS just like the rest of
the milestones in that request.

614
00:30:55.220 --> 00:30:56.319
Yep.

615
00:30:56.319 --> 00:30:57.419
>> All right Terry,

616
00:30:57.419 --> 00:31:02.048
when we take a look there's a few other
things that we need to address here.

617
00:31:02.048 --> 00:31:05.098
We need to talk about
some types of changes and

618
00:31:05.098 --> 00:31:08.239
even some idea of some
remediation planning.

619
00:31:08.239 --> 00:31:12.320
But we are kind of heading close
to the end of our time together.

620
00:31:12.320 --> 00:31:15.220
Any last words on just
what we've covered so far,

621
00:31:15.220 --> 00:31:17.020
because I think we're just
going to go on to a part two.

622
00:31:17.020 --> 00:31:18.520
>> I think that's a great idea,
and you're right,

623
00:31:18.520 --> 00:31:20.690
I think that's a good place to
start the next conversation.

624
00:31:20.690 --> 00:31:25.090
We kind of set the table here that you
need to get change under control, and

625
00:31:25.090 --> 00:31:28.220
that you're going to have a mechanism
of getting the change requests in, and

626
00:31:28.220 --> 00:31:32.490
evaluate them, assessing risk and
value and cost, right.

627
00:31:32.490 --> 00:31:35.560
And once that's done you can
then proceed with the change.

628
00:31:35.560 --> 00:31:38.490
But how do we categorize these changes
would be a great place to start

629
00:31:38.490 --> 00:31:39.232
in the next episode.

630
00:31:39.232 --> 00:31:41.020
>> All right, well that sounds great.

631
00:31:41.020 --> 00:31:44.980
Thank you again Terry for helping us to
at least get started in understanding how

632
00:31:44.980 --> 00:31:48.416
important change management is and
the control of it as well.

633
00:31:48.416 --> 00:31:51.590
And that means that we actually have
a lot more to cover as we start diving

634
00:31:51.590 --> 00:31:52.410
a little bit deeper.

635
00:31:52.410 --> 00:31:55.510
So you want to make sure that you
stay around for that part two.

636
00:31:55.510 --> 00:31:59.100
Signing off for
ITProTV I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

637
00:31:59.100 --> 00:32:00.340
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

638
00:32:00.340 --> 00:32:05.248
>> Stay tuned right here for
more ITIL Release, Control and Validation.

639
00:32:05.248 --> 00:32:11.274
[MUSIC]

640
00:32:11.274 --> 00:32:14.454
>> Thank you for watching, ITPROTV.

Some aspects of execution involve planning and scheduling as well reviewing the changes to set the priority and urgency of the change.

WEBVTT

00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:01.372

I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

00:00:21.350 --> 00:00:25.460
We're specifically going into a part two

00:00:25.460 --> 00:00:28.990
understand not only the importance

Mr Terry Decker.

Terry, welcome back to the studios.

13
00:00:35.540 --> 00:00:36.500
>> Glad to be here Ronnie.

14
00:00:36.500 --> 00:00:39.117
And as you said we're going
to look at some review here.

15
00:00:39.117 --> 00:00:40.913
We'll see some terminology and

16

some concepts that we got from foundations
replayed here and remind ourselves just

17
00:00:45.571 --> 00:00:49.380
what change management has in it's
toolkit to make it successful.

18
00:00:50.610 --> 00:00:55.030
First of all, as a definition of
changes and the types of changes.

19
00:00:55.030 --> 00:00:59.340
If you look at the graphic here,
you'll see that ITIL describes three

20
00:00:59.340 --> 00:01:02.230
types of change, normal,
standard, and emergency.

21
00:01:02.230 --> 00:01:04.610

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Terry continue with some of the broad concepts of SACM.  They discuss the need to using a Configuration Management System with assets and configuration items as our main interface with the data from multiple systems holding asset and configuration information.  Along with this, they also take a look at the use of software and controlling software through the DML, the definitive media library.  These are foundational items needed for activities normally performed during the SACM process!

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Terry continue with a part 3 of understanding SACM.  They take a look at the concept of release, the accountability of execution.  This is important concept to know not only who but the scope of the change according to the team.  Terry also helps us to take at controls that need to be in place for the release to happen.  Part of the best practices with SACM is also accounting and reporting along with verification and auditing, says Terry.   They end with a brief overall review of the major concepts of SACM.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Terry introduce the process called service validation & testing.  They a look at the purpose of service validation and testing as a way of instilling confidence in the providers service.  The goal is to provide the better service to the customer by using testing models to eliminate pain points of service, according to the team.  Terry also emphasizes the key drivers to this process is the establishment and enforcement of good policies.  They also briefly introduce testing models and understanding the perspective of service customer.  They end with a brief look at continual service improvement as well.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Terry take a look at the activities involved with service validation & testing.  The team points out how validation and testing is adding controls that will be helpful in management, function and business value to the service provided.  SV&T helps in management by providing the steps needed to insure that we provide proper testing, according to the guys.  They emphasize that the result is a better product that functions well at the level we indicated and of course makes the product a valuable tool for the provider and a valued service for the customer.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Terry discuss the important process of Release & Deployment Management.  This goes beyond authorization into managing the execution of solutions, changes and elements we introduce into our IT environment, according to Terry.  They describe the nature, scope of the process as well as its business value to the customer and provider.  Terry also briefly describes the importance of policies to help with the process management.  They also define some terminology that is common in the realm of deployment management.

comes from operations, and is managed

207
00:10:01.900 --> 00:10:05.580
through transitional processes, change,
release, deployment, and testing, right?

208
00:10:05.580 --> 00:10:09.030
And that's just managed without bothering
service design and service strategy.

209
00:10:09.030 --> 00:10:14.270
That's certainly viable, but
replacing Lotus Notes with SharePoint

210
00:10:14.270 --> 00:10:16.990
is something that probably went all
the way up to service strategy,

211
00:10:16.990 --> 00:10:20.880
worked its way through the cost benefit
analysis, got appropriate design,

212
00:10:20.880 --> 00:10:24.350
got appropriate transition planning,
and then became operational.

213
00:10:24.350 --> 00:10:28.280
So, it really is a matter of scale,
whether you consider operations,

214
00:10:28.280 --> 00:10:31.380
whether you consider change
management as part of operations, or

215
00:10:31.380 --> 00:10:33.800
part of some other life cycle stage.

216
00:10:34.820 --> 00:10:37.450
It's clear that ITIL's clearly
puts change management in

217
00:10:37.450 --> 00:10:40.720
the transition life cycle stage,
make no mistake about that, but

218
00:10:40.720 --> 00:10:44.880
that that transition stage could be
evoked directly from operations,

219
00:10:44.880 --> 00:10:48.380
without the involvement of strategy and
design is viable.

220
00:10:48.380 --> 00:10:52.240
>> All right, so, just like
everything else, in every process

221
00:10:52.240 --> 00:10:55.920
we've talked about the idea of
an owner as well as a Process Manager.

222
00:10:55.920 --> 00:10:58.538
What are the responsibilities when
we start taking a look at this?

223
00:10:58.538 --> 00:11:03.270
>> The generic responsibilities and
accountabilities of owner and

224
00:11:03.270 --> 00:11:04.910
manager are the same.

225
00:11:05.940 --> 00:11:07.650
As a processor owner for
release and deployment,

226
00:11:07.650 --> 00:11:10.960
you need to make sure the quality
of this process is up.

227
00:11:10.960 --> 00:11:15.300
You got a good, high quality process,
which means continual improvement,

228
00:11:15.300 --> 00:11:18.650
measurement of the process, continual and

229
00:11:18.650 --> 00:11:22.920
gradual progress toward a great process,
right?

230
00:11:22.920 --> 00:11:26.140
So, that's what the process
owner's gonna be responsible for.

231
00:11:26.140 --> 00:11:27.860
As we talked about generically before,

232
00:11:27.860 --> 00:11:31.050
the process manager is
involved with the day to day.

233
00:11:31.050 --> 00:11:35.150
So, a release and deployment process
manager is a busy person, right?

234
00:11:35.150 --> 00:11:39.620
You probably have many of these,
not just one manager, right?

235
00:11:39.620 --> 00:11:42.450
You can also combine roles as
we've talked about before.

236
00:11:42.450 --> 00:11:47.060
So, the generic treatment of owner and
manager will serve you well conceptually.

237
00:11:47.060 --> 00:11:50.970
But just understand that this
process is a busy process, right?

238
00:11:50.970 --> 00:11:54.140
It's got lots of things to do,
lots of things to consider,

239
00:11:54.140 --> 00:11:57.680
lots of data inputs and a time scale
that's pretty short sometimes.

240
00:11:58.820 --> 00:12:02.230
>> Now, and Terry, the other thing that I
think might be a little bit different, and

241
00:12:02.230 --> 00:12:05.190
you'll have to correct me if I'm wrong
here, is that you talk about the idea

242
00:12:05.190 --> 00:12:07.650
of a practitioner, but
in this role of release and

243
00:12:07.650 --> 00:12:11.680
deployment, you might have two different
types of practitioners, right?

244
00:12:11.680 --> 00:12:14.290
One for packaging and one for deployment.

245
00:12:14.290 --> 00:12:16.201
Why do we need to differentiate those out?

246
00:12:16.201 --> 00:12:17.430
>> Good point.

247
00:12:17.430 --> 00:12:18.780
It depends on the complexity
of the change,

248
00:12:18.780 --> 00:12:20.770
it's a technical complexity as well.

249
00:12:20.770 --> 00:12:23.300
Consider that deployment
means a lot of things,

250
00:12:23.300 --> 00:12:26.850
it's not just deploying technology,
it's getting people trained.

251
00:12:26.850 --> 00:12:29.750
It's getting processes updated.

252
00:12:29.750 --> 00:12:33.980
It's doing lots of things that
make this service possible, and

253
00:12:33.980 --> 00:12:35.720
not just solution possible.

254
00:12:35.720 --> 00:12:39.125
So, when you consider that kind of scope,
service versus solution,

255
00:12:39.125 --> 00:12:43.282
you're probably going to devolve into some
areas of specialty where you're going to

256
00:12:43.282 --> 00:12:44.744
have your technical people.

257
00:12:44.744 --> 00:12:47.886
And then you're gonna have the folks
that are more customer facing,

258
00:12:47.886 --> 00:12:51.110
dealing with UAT, test execution,
and stuff like that.

259
00:12:51.110 --> 00:12:55.810
You recall earlier that we separated
the duties of building from

260
00:12:55.810 --> 00:13:00.076
the duties of testing, so in that regard,
you have different practitioners as well.

261
00:13:00.076 --> 00:13:05.850
>> Now, I just realized something as I was
looking down here trying to see something.

262
00:13:05.850 --> 00:13:07.029
I'm gonna do an acronym check on you.

263
00:13:07.029 --> 00:13:08.000
>> Okay, sure.

264
00:13:08.000 --> 00:13:10.830
>> Which is, you also have ELS.

265
00:13:10.830 --> 00:13:12.794
Early life support practitioner.

266
00:13:12.794 --> 00:13:13.506
>> Yeah.

267
00:13:13.506 --> 00:13:14.923
>> Somebody know CPR?

268
00:13:14.923 --> 00:13:15.631
Is that what we're talking about?

269
00:13:15.631 --> 00:13:16.920
>> Kind of, but no.

270
00:13:16.920 --> 00:13:18.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, early life support,

271
00:13:19.500 --> 00:13:23.760
often built into project plans for
a new launch of a service,

272
00:13:23.760 --> 00:13:28.610
is a period of time where the project
stays in play after launch.

273
00:13:28.610 --> 00:13:33.260
It can be used to mitigate any big
problems that were unforeseen.

274
00:13:33.260 --> 00:13:36.900
It could be used for
additional training of service desk staff.

275
00:13:36.900 --> 00:13:41.370
It could be the marriage of the project
and the service desk staff for

276
00:13:41.370 --> 00:13:42.700
a temporary time, right?

277
00:13:42.700 --> 00:13:47.580
To make sure there's appropriate knowledge
transfer in a real live environment.

278
00:13:48.700 --> 00:13:52.240
Sometimes, where life support is
defined within a project scope,

279
00:13:52.240 --> 00:13:56.120
particularly funded for a specific time,
I've sort of seen that play out,

280
00:13:56.120 --> 00:13:59.280
that seems to be the most
reasonable in real life.

281
00:13:59.280 --> 00:14:03.630
ITIL happens to preach it a little bit
differently, that early life support is

282
00:14:03.630 --> 00:14:09.280
that period of time between service
launch and service acceptance.

283
00:14:09.280 --> 00:14:13.750
They don't put a timeline on it, whatever
it takes to get it accepted, right?

284
00:14:13.750 --> 00:14:17.100
So, if you launch something
that's got lots of problems,

285
00:14:17.100 --> 00:14:20.310
you need to resolve all those
problems before life support is over.

286
00:14:20.310 --> 00:14:22.540
That's how ITIL positions it, right?

287
00:14:22.540 --> 00:14:24.010
A little bit differently, and

288
00:14:24.010 --> 00:14:28.870
maybe somewhat impractical when you're
trying to budget a project for it.

289
00:14:28.870 --> 00:14:32.130
Those tend to be capitalized funds or
operational funds.

290
00:14:32.130 --> 00:14:36.020
Whatever the funding source is,
it's a finite amount.

291
00:14:36.020 --> 00:14:38.210
And to say, I need another extra
hundred thousand dollars for

292
00:14:38.210 --> 00:14:42.655
three more months of early life support,
you're probably not gonna be very popular.

293
00:14:42.655 --> 00:14:43.290
>> [LAUGH]
>> So again,

294
00:14:43.290 --> 00:14:46.800
the practical approach is probably gonna
be more some sort of hybrid of that,

295
00:14:46.800 --> 00:14:49.420
where early life support is active for
awhile.

296
00:14:49.420 --> 00:14:51.200
They try to mitigate as many
problems as they want, and

297
00:14:51.200 --> 00:14:55.722
they are certain to make the risk register
manageable before they stand down.

298
00:14:55.722 --> 00:14:59.540
>> All right, our final particular role
that we have and we want to know about

299
00:14:59.540 --> 00:15:03.890
the responsibilities is the build and
test environment manager as well.

300
00:15:03.890 --> 00:15:08.970
So, how is this different from the Process
Manager we were talking about before?

301
00:15:08.970 --> 00:15:09.805
>> Good point.

302
00:15:09.805 --> 00:15:12.680
ITIL is certainly
highlighting a key factor.

303
00:15:12.680 --> 00:15:15.700
What ITIL has done,
the way it's grown over the years

304
00:15:15.700 --> 00:15:17.980
is through practical experience,
doing research,

305
00:15:17.980 --> 00:15:21.760
going into organizations finding out
what works well, what doesn't work well.

306
00:15:21.760 --> 00:15:25.320
So, defining this role called Build and
Test Environment Manager, again,

307
00:15:25.320 --> 00:15:27.610
keep in mind this is not
an organizational structure.

308
00:15:27.610 --> 00:15:30.990
You might be the early life
support practitioner and

309
00:15:30.990 --> 00:15:32.430
the build and tested environment manager.

310
00:15:32.430 --> 00:15:34.770
A given person could
play more than one role.

311
00:15:34.770 --> 00:15:37.330
But identifying this role means you're

312
00:15:37.330 --> 00:15:40.380
identifying someone that's
going to be accountable for

313
00:15:40.380 --> 00:15:44.380
ensuring the integrity of the live
environment and the test environment.

314
00:15:46.250 --> 00:15:50.650
The primary reason why tests fail
is not because in production and

315
00:15:50.650 --> 00:15:55.830
operations, it's not necessarily because
the code was built wrong, necessarily.

316
00:15:55.830 --> 00:15:58.770
It's because it was tested in
an environment that didn't mimic

317
00:15:58.770 --> 00:15:59.680
the live environment.

318
00:15:59.680 --> 00:16:01.680
That's a common occurrence, right?

319
00:16:01.680 --> 00:16:03.170
I wouldn't say it's number one or
number two,

320
00:16:03.170 --> 00:16:08.090
but it's a common occurrence in that you
gotta have these environments controlled.

321
00:16:08.090 --> 00:16:11.980
So, identifying a role to take
care of those environments

322
00:16:11.980 --> 00:16:15.660
is a step that ITIL says you should make,
to make sure you have accountability for

323
00:16:15.660 --> 00:16:18.060
that very important aspect.

324
00:16:18.060 --> 00:16:18.730
>> All right Terry,

325
00:16:18.730 --> 00:16:23.775
well, that is, again, another big
process that we've taking a look at.

326
00:16:23.775 --> 00:16:27.720
With a lot of deep concepts that we really
should take the time to think about, and

327
00:16:27.720 --> 00:16:31.260
make sure that we understand before
going into that example as well.

328
00:16:31.260 --> 00:16:36.490
So Terry, is there any particular
focus that I should have

329
00:16:36.490 --> 00:16:42.000
in my mind before getting ready, or as
I'm preparing for the exam at this point?

330
00:16:42.000 --> 00:16:45.190
>> Not specifically, I'll give you
the same advice I had given before.

331
00:16:45.190 --> 00:16:48.750
Those practice exams that you
have access to are valuable.

332
00:16:48.750 --> 00:16:53.480
Take one or two of the questions that are
focused on release and deploy management,

333
00:16:53.480 --> 00:16:56.300
and change management, and
you'll reinforce these.

334
00:16:56.300 --> 00:17:00.110
At the same time, you'll be getting
inside the mind of the test maker, and

335
00:17:00.110 --> 00:17:03.862
understanding just how they test
against the objectives of the test.

336
00:17:03.862 --> 00:17:05.390
>> All right, Terry, well, thank you for

337
00:17:05.390 --> 00:17:09.560
helping us to understand the concept of
release and deployment management better.

338
00:17:09.560 --> 00:17:11.940
You remember, you've gotta review these.

339
00:17:11.940 --> 00:17:12.640
Just like I did,

340
00:17:12.640 --> 00:17:16.290
even though I've been doing these shows
with Terry, it was still very easy for me

341
00:17:16.290 --> 00:17:20.810
not to be able to come up with the answers
right then when we've been doing this.

342
00:17:20.810 --> 00:17:22.190
But a lot of times though,

343
00:17:22.190 --> 00:17:24.800
you can have that same anxiety
as you go in on the test.

344
00:17:24.800 --> 00:17:28.863
So, preparation is the key as
you prepare for that as well.

345
00:17:28.863 --> 00:17:31.788
You're also gonna see that these
concepts will appear over and

346
00:17:31.788 --> 00:17:35.153
over again, just like we've seen now
a pattern through every process,

347
00:17:35.153 --> 00:17:39.030
there's a lot of things that do, not so
much overlap, but you see the same things.

348
00:17:39.030 --> 00:17:40.400
When we're talking about risk and

349
00:17:40.400 --> 00:17:43.810
challenges, as well as the idea
of roles and responsibilities.

350
00:17:43.810 --> 00:17:47.010
All of these are key factors in every
process we've been talking about.

351
00:17:47.010 --> 00:17:50.870
So make sure you go back over them, make
sure you actually do have them solemnly in

352
00:17:50.870 --> 00:17:54.010
your mind before getting,
as you're getting ready for your exam.

353
00:17:54.010 --> 00:17:57.080
But it's also a great place for
us to end this episode then.

354
00:17:57.080 --> 00:18:00.334
Signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

355
00:18:00.334 --> 00:18:01.499
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

356
00:18:01.499 --> 00:18:05.770
>> Stay tuned right here for more ITIL,
release control and validation.

357
00:18:05.770 --> 00:18:12.659
[MUSIC]

358
00:18:12.659 --> 00:18:15.948
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Terry take us through the concepts of request fulfillment.  They emphasize the goal request fulfillment is not so much about incident management as it is about fulfilling planned expectations.  They also discuss request fulfillment in terms of using a self-fulfillment portal or a service desk.  The key is not so much about the system that is in place but the formalization,adoption, and use of the system that is implemented along the way.  Also the team discusses the basic challenges and risks associated with request fulfillment process.
episodes.title: Request Fulfillment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.062 --> 00:00:01.338
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.338 --> 00:00:04.759
I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.759 --> 00:00:08.277
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.277 --> 00:00:12.680
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.680 --> 00:00:15.750
>> Welcome to another great
episode here on ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:15.750 --> 00:00:17.260
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:17.260 --> 00:00:21.540
And today, we're taking a look at
ITIL release, control and validation.

8
00:00:21.540 --> 00:00:24.350
We're diving into request fulfillment, and

9
00:00:24.350 --> 00:00:28.040
here to help us out is gonna be our
ITIL expert himself, Mr. Terry Decker.

10
00:00:28.040 --> 00:00:29.510
Terry, welcome back to the studios.

11
00:00:29.510 --> 00:00:30.590
>> Glad to be here, Ronnie.

12
00:00:30.590 --> 00:00:31.870
>> Yep.

13
00:00:31.870 --> 00:00:33.940
>> So, as we're gonna dig in
today into request fulfillment,

14
00:00:33.940 --> 00:00:35.590
I'm gonna start with
a very simple question.

15
00:00:35.590 --> 00:00:38.928
In fact, Ron, I'll even ask you,
what is a request?

16
00:00:38.928 --> 00:00:42.208
>> As I start thinking
about the idea of requests,

17
00:00:42.208 --> 00:00:46.230
Terry, I always think about
things in terms of help desk.

18
00:00:46.230 --> 00:00:49.268
A lot of times,
there's something that I asked for,

19
00:00:49.268 --> 00:00:53.810
because I don't know where to find
something, or something is broken.

20
00:00:53.810 --> 00:00:58.790
Or it could be that I don't have what I
need I need right now at my desk, and

21
00:00:58.790 --> 00:01:01.830
I need something else to tell
me to do what I need to do.

22
00:01:01.830 --> 00:01:04.480
>> Well, that's good,
and almost right 100%.

23
00:01:04.480 --> 00:01:06.900
You mentioned,
I don't know where something is, so

24
00:01:06.900 --> 00:01:07.960
you call the service desk.

25
00:01:07.960 --> 00:01:12.088
That's certainly something the service
desk is gonna be keen to answer for you,

26
00:01:12.088 --> 00:01:13.738
and do so efficiently, right?

27
00:01:13.738 --> 00:01:17.822
I need to find where this application is,
or I need a new headset.

28
00:01:17.822 --> 00:01:21.060
You mentioned something though, that
actually, ITIL would call an incident.

29
00:01:21.060 --> 00:01:24.090
This things not working,
I need it to work.

30
00:01:24.090 --> 00:01:26.420
So then, the service desk
was trying to fix something.

31
00:01:26.420 --> 00:01:30.624
So, service is somehow diminished,
because something's broken,

32
00:01:30.624 --> 00:01:33.986
then that's an incident,
we need to restore service.

33
00:01:33.986 --> 00:01:38.670
So, this idea of fulfilling requests
means you're fulfilling a need,

34
00:01:38.670 --> 00:01:42.218
on a routine basis,
in a repeatable process, right?

35
00:01:42.218 --> 00:01:45.418
So I need a new headset,
where is that application,

36
00:01:45.418 --> 00:01:48.660
can you install this software for
me, right?

37
00:01:48.660 --> 00:01:52.170
My battery is not recharging,
can you replace the battery?

38
00:01:52.170 --> 00:01:54.421
The types of things that customer needs,

39
00:01:54.421 --> 00:01:58.342
or the user needs to use your service
would be the kind of things that would

40
00:01:58.342 --> 00:02:01.059
be requested in a standard
fulfillment process.

41
00:02:01.059 --> 00:02:06.096
So, requests fulfillment, as a process, is
the methodical way you go about defining

42
00:02:06.096 --> 00:02:10.657
what is requestable, and make sure you
fulfill those requests efficiently.

43
00:02:10.657 --> 00:02:14.199
>> All right, so Terry, let me ask this
question then, since you made this

44
00:02:14.199 --> 00:02:18.300
distinction between the idea of
a service request and an incident.

45
00:02:18.300 --> 00:02:21.590
Why aren't they the same thing if I'm
saying hey, there's something wrong,

46
00:02:21.590 --> 00:02:23.740
versus what you're talking about?

47
00:02:23.740 --> 00:02:26.020
>> Well,
consider the scale of what could be wrong.

48
00:02:26.020 --> 00:02:32.100
You might get a user that calls to service
desk and says, I can't the submit button,

49
00:02:32.100 --> 00:02:36.670
and you might just consider well,
that's just an uninformed user, right?

50
00:02:36.670 --> 00:02:40.430
So, you remind the user that there is a
scroll bar, and they can scroll down, and

51
00:02:40.430 --> 00:02:41.680
the submit button is down below.

52
00:02:41.680 --> 00:02:43.500
They just can't see it.

53
00:02:43.500 --> 00:02:47.090
>> Or, what if 30 people called
the service desk and says,

54
00:02:47.090 --> 00:02:49.170
I can't find the submit button?

55
00:02:49.170 --> 00:02:53.280
Maybe the change you did this past weekend
accidentally removed the submit button.

56
00:02:53.280 --> 00:02:53.990
>> Mm-hm.
>> Right?

57
00:02:53.990 --> 00:02:55.000
>> Right.
>> So,

58
00:02:55.000 --> 00:02:57.520
there you see there's
something you have to fix.

59
00:02:57.520 --> 00:03:00.290
In that latter example,
you have to go fix something.

60
00:03:00.290 --> 00:03:04.120
And the first example is just really
giving the user some information.

61
00:03:04.120 --> 00:03:06.550
So, a request for
information to help a user out,

62
00:03:06.550 --> 00:03:10.130
because they're not quite fully
informed is the nature of the request.

63
00:03:10.130 --> 00:03:12.700
And again, maybe to utilize a service,

64
00:03:12.700 --> 00:03:17.820
you need a special piece of equipment,
or you need, like I said,

65
00:03:17.820 --> 00:03:20.450
a headset, or you need to replace your
battery and those kind of things.

66
00:03:20.450 --> 00:03:23.220
So, those standard fulfillment options

67
00:03:23.220 --> 00:03:26.462
would also be under the rubric
of request fulfillment.

68
00:03:26.462 --> 00:03:27.640
>> Al right, so Terry,

69
00:03:27.640 --> 00:03:31.800
why in the world are we talking about
this idea of request fulfillment then?

70
00:03:31.800 --> 00:03:33.700
In terms of release control and
validation,

71
00:03:33.700 --> 00:03:37.810
I don't hear anything about a release, I
don't here anything about a control here,

72
00:03:37.810 --> 00:03:40.820
and definitely not any validation,
so why are we talking about here?

73

episodes.description: {Description}In this episode, Ronnie and Terry introduce a subset process of change management: change evaluation.  They describe the need for change evaluation is normally on a larger scope in terms of business strategy rather than on a technical implementation level.  These types of evaluations can effect the business outcome, the service operation and even the infrastructure of the organization, according to the guys.  Terry also describes some of key terminology, activities and factors (STORMPUP) that must be considered in the change evaluation.  Lastly, they summary the entire process with reminder to try and apply the knowledge learned!

1

23

24

25

26

As time went on and

the ITIL librarians that is, that change

good do a compare and contrast.

73
00:04:14.840 --> 00:04:19.440
What I mean by that is, let's say you

00:04:19.440 --> 00:04:21.750
This is something a lot of

77
00:04:28.000 --> 00:04:29.810
Right they just cost less.

78
00:04:29.810 --> 00:04:33.430

79
00:04:33.430 --> 00:04:35.780
The customer may say, so.

80
00:04:35.780 --> 00:04:39.270

83
00:04:45.170 --> 00:04:49.050
So change evaluation will

85
00:04:51.280 --> 00:04:52.710
Sure, we're becoming more efficient.

86
00:04:52.710 --> 00:04:54.220
What does that mean to the users?

87
00:04:54.220 --> 00:04:55.280
Maybe we're saving money.

88
00:04:55.280 --> 00:04:56.541
What does that mean to the end users?

89
00:04:56.541 --> 00:05:01.220
Right maybe we can be more
flexible in providing service and

90
00:05:01.220 --> 00:05:05.580

91
00:05:05.580 --> 00:05:07.700

00:05:33.970 --> 00:05:36.210

the data that we need to

So the predictive part is you

not I'm going to need

00:26:11.510 --> 00:26:13.230
IT's capabilities.

as in the example we've used

00:27:49.870 --> 00:27:50.760
>> All right.

00:27:50.760 --> 00:27:54.882
Yeah sometimes you just get that because

like, you're gonna be working on change

The entire goal is have the knowledge ready for how needs it at the right time, according to the team.  They review the constant idea of the need and the scope.  With the nature of the ocean of information there of course needs one some type of system (SKMS) to help with the management, distribution and use of the data available, according to the guys. 496
00:25:48.120 --> 00:25:51.920
much more efficient without having to
go and find the information itself.

497
00:25:51.920 --> 00:25:56.030
This is one of the key aspects, of course,
of understanding ITIL's framework.

498
00:25:56.030 --> 00:25:59.495
Because it makes everything a bit more
efficient, it actually ends up reducing

499
00:25:59.495 --> 00:26:02.611
cost and later on, as you're actually
trying to do some of the things.

500
00:26:02.611 --> 00:26:06.240
So make sure you have
this concept mastered or

501
00:26:06.240 --> 00:26:11.850
at least understood very easily
before you go in for that exam.

502
00:26:11.850 --> 00:26:14.470
Well, that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

503
00:26:14.470 --> 00:26:17.610
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

504
00:26:17.610 --> 00:26:18.610
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

505
00:26:18.610 --> 00:26:23.214
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL: Release, Control, and Validation.

506
00:26:23.214 --> 00:26:29.172
[MUSIC]

507
00:26:29.172 --> 00:26:32.360
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie & Terry take us back to the big picture of Service Management.  They explain the importance of keeping the big picture and not just the individual processes.  They remind us that each process is part of the whole and should be seen that way to help with a successful implementation of ITIL into our organization
episodes.title: Technology and Implementation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.446
Welcome to IT Pro TV,

2
00:00:03.446 --> 00:00:08.412
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.412 --> 00:00:10.450
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:12.700 --> 00:00:15.820
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:15.820 --> 00:00:19.700
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
today we're taking a look at ITIL Release,

6
00:00:19.700 --> 00:00:21.330
Control, and Validation.

7
00:00:21.330 --> 00:00:24.210
We're specifically going to be taking
a look here at some of the different

8
00:00:24.210 --> 00:00:28.400
considerations such as technology and
implementation here and

9
00:00:28.400 --> 00:00:31.680
with us is going to be our ITIL expert,
Mister Terry Decker.

10
00:00:31.680 --> 00:00:35.130
Terry, welcome back to the show and
tell us what we're talking about here,

11
00:00:35.130 --> 00:00:38.210
when we start talking about all these
ideas of technology and implementation.

12
00:00:38.210 --> 00:00:41.020
>> Well fundamentally,
ITIL is is about service management.

13
00:00:41.020 --> 00:00:43.290
It's not about technology selection or

14
00:00:43.290 --> 00:00:45.530
even implementation planning,
those types of things.

15
00:00:45.530 --> 00:00:48.140
So this treatment is gonna
be very superficial.

16
00:00:48.140 --> 00:00:51.960
And if you've had any other intermediate
courses, you'll find actually a quite

17
00:00:51.960 --> 00:00:55.640
generic treatment of the same topics
of technology and implementation.

18
00:00:55.640 --> 00:00:57.060
So let's have a dive here.

19
00:00:57.060 --> 00:01:00.410
Just quickly,
if you look at the graphic here,

20
00:01:00.410 --> 00:01:04.040
some of the core functionality for
ITSM tools.

21
00:01:04.040 --> 00:01:06.693
You can certainly read the bullets there,
but

22
00:01:06.693 --> 00:01:10.502
I can summarize this in some ways is that,
you need to be looking for

23
00:01:10.502 --> 00:01:14.124
tool sets that allow you to
manage your services effectively.

24
00:01:14.124 --> 00:01:20.026
And that's gonna be Including integration
across multiple processes, visibility,

25
00:01:20.026 --> 00:01:25.900
discovery, metrics, reporting,
perhaps remote control, self help systems.

26
00:01:25.900 --> 00:01:30.340
Those are the types of technologies that
are gonna enable you to be more flexible

27
00:01:30.340 --> 00:01:32.340
and more focused on the customers and

28
00:01:32.340 --> 00:01:35.600
the business end and
streamline delivery of your services.

29
00:01:35.600 --> 00:01:39.780
>> Now Terry, as you start talking
about this idea, is there a,

30
00:01:39.780 --> 00:01:41.950
a way that we should rank these?

31
00:01:41.950 --> 00:01:44.460
If we say look, I know that
there's no way that I can look for

32
00:01:44.460 --> 00:01:45.960
every single one of these, Terry.

33
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:50.360
What, what would you consider kind of
the top ones that we might focus on?

34
00:01:50.360 --> 00:01:52.660
>> Well,
it's going to depend on the organization.

35
00:01:52.660 --> 00:01:56.380
There's no real prescription here for
not one size fits all.

36
00:01:56.380 --> 00:01:59.290
You might be a highly
evolved service management

37
00:01:59.290 --> 00:02:02.970
organization where you're just
improving your existing technologies.

38
00:02:02.970 --> 00:02:06.410
You might be starting from scratch and
haven't even picked a tool set for

39
00:02:06.410 --> 00:02:07.900
your service management suite.

40
00:02:07.900 --> 00:02:10.700
So there's no real set approach to this.

41
00:02:10.700 --> 00:02:15.320
The best approach would be a continual
service improvement approach

42
00:02:15.320 --> 00:02:18.660
where you look at the critical areas,
work on them first,

43
00:02:18.660 --> 00:02:23.050
squeeze some value out of that and
continually and gradually move forward.

44
00:02:23.050 --> 00:02:26.490
If you're an exam taker I think that's
also gonna be an important lesson to take

45
00:02:26.490 --> 00:02:27.440
away as well.

46
00:02:27.440 --> 00:02:30.600
Is that you're going to focus
on continual and gradual and

47
00:02:30.600 --> 00:02:34.570
don't just leap to the big
solution in the sky right away.

48
00:02:34.570 --> 00:02:38.130
So as you get choices on the exam, there
will be one that looks really promising,

49
00:02:38.130 --> 00:02:43.400
especially to an IT person that wants to
solve problems with big solutions, but

50
00:02:43.400 --> 00:02:46.340
it's probably going to be more, the more
correct answer's going to be the answer

51
00:02:46.340 --> 00:02:50.540
that leads you toward a measured
approach where you look before you leap.

52
00:02:50.540 --> 00:02:53.980
And I think that'd be true for
your technology limitation as well.

53
00:02:53.980 --> 00:02:58.500
>> And the idea of thinking about
evaluating what particular tools we need

54
00:02:58.500 --> 00:03:02.080
versus the ones that we don't, it still
seems challenging because every tool that

55
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:06.520
you might consider seems to say of course
we can do this, of course we can do this.

56
00:03:06.520 --> 00:03:10.880
And so in this particular sense
we may actually have to deal and

57
00:03:10.880 --> 00:03:14.610
kind of weed through a lot more
marketing than anything else and

58
00:03:14.610 --> 00:03:17.610
then figure out what solutions
really fit best for us, right?

59
00:03:17.610 --> 00:03:21.700
>> Of course, imagine talking to a tool
set vendor, if you're going to go out and

60
00:03:21.700 --> 00:03:23.760
not develop it in house,
you're talking to a tool set vendor.

61
00:03:23.760 --> 00:03:27.060
They're going to be selling you
things and, in that sales pitch,

62
00:03:27.060 --> 00:03:30.600
there's going to be real valuable things
and perhaps some less valuable things.

63
00:03:30.600 --> 00:03:34.140
So understanding what value you're
trying to get out of these tool sets

64
00:03:34.140 --> 00:03:34.640
is an important.

65
00:03:34.640 --> 00:03:38.760
If you look at the graphic here, you
become in charge of this rather than let

66
00:03:38.760 --> 00:03:42.260
the sales effort lead you to
the water you need to drink.

67
00:03:42.260 --> 00:03:46.190
You get on top of this and you understand
what it is you're trying to get done.

68
00:03:46.190 --> 00:03:48.340
This is rather serpentine here but

69
00:03:48.340 --> 00:03:52.420
it really is just a linear process
where you identify your requirements.

70
00:03:52.420 --> 00:03:57.280
What products potentially could be in
scope for delivering those particular

71
00:03:58.430 --> 00:04:01.420
functionality, set of functionality and
scale.

72
00:04:01.420 --> 00:04:04.020
And then develop your selection criteria.

73
00:04:04.020 --> 00:04:08.250
As we look at this next slide, just wanna
show you as you look at your selection

74
00:04:08.250 --> 00:04:12.270
criteria you're looking for those
things that you must have, should have,

75
00:04:12.270 --> 00:04:16.870
could have or perhaps you'll have in
the future but you don't have right now.

76
00:04:16.870 --> 00:04:20.430
It's probably going to be pretty much
impossible to find a tool set that

77
00:04:20.430 --> 00:04:24.290
matches one percent of what
you're looking for, but

78
00:04:24.290 --> 00:04:27.690
as a rule of thumb you should focus
on your process definition first and

79
00:04:27.690 --> 00:04:30.950
your process objectives and
then let the tools follow.

80
00:04:32.060 --> 00:04:36.490
Again, easier said than done because
as your engaging with these vendors,

81
00:04:36.490 --> 00:04:40.080
they're going to try to lead you and,
legitimately so,

82
00:04:40.080 --> 00:04:42.960
to how their tools provide
value that's legitimate.

83
00:04:42.960 --> 00:04:47.500
But you need to focus on your processes
first and then look at the tools.

84
00:04:47.500 --> 00:04:51.830
Another good rule of thumb is that,
as you discerned what you must have,

85
00:04:51.830 --> 00:04:55.130
you want to make sure that
100% of those are satisfied.

86
00:04:55.130 --> 00:04:58.060
If you've gone the trouble of
analyzing your requirements and

87
00:04:58.060 --> 00:05:00.837
know what you must have,
then don't compromise on those.

88
00:05:00.837 --> 00:05:04.550
Go after those 100% of the time.

89
00:05:04.550 --> 00:05:07.850
It's unlikely you're gonna get something
that's gonna take care of everything.

90
00:05:07.850 --> 00:05:12.030
So for those other things that aren't
must haves, consider the 80 20 rule.

91
00:05:12.030 --> 00:05:16.020
If a tool set can give you 80% of
the functionality you're looking for

92
00:05:16.020 --> 00:05:17.480
then it's a good bet.

93
00:05:17.480 --> 00:05:22.237
>> All right, now Terry, along with this
idea and thinking about those different

94
00:05:22.237 --> 00:05:26.924
tools that are available, there also
comes this unusual thing that happens.

95
00:05:26.924 --> 00:05:27.988
And I've seen it happen and

96
00:05:27.988 --> 00:05:30.620
you've probably seen it happen
with just even hardware.

97
00:05:30.620 --> 00:05:35.440
Where you buy it, and three months later
that particular tool that you thought was

98
00:05:35.440 --> 00:05:38.170
really gonna be the thing
that does everything.

99
00:05:38.170 --> 00:05:39.840
It now seems a little bit dated.

100
00:05:39.840 --> 00:05:41.660
It doesn't work as well.

101
00:05:41.660 --> 00:05:44.770
So is there anything that kind
of helps us to think about

102
00:05:44.770 --> 00:05:46.390
future proofing a little bit?

103
00:05:46.390 --> 00:05:48.390
Or is that just kind of
a pipe dream of saying,

104
00:05:48.390 --> 00:05:51.290
there's no way we're gonna actually
be able to say six months from now

105
00:05:51.290 --> 00:05:54.400
the tools that we select
are really going to help us here?

106
00:05:54.400 --> 00:05:56.750
>> Well, there's good news on this front.

107
00:05:56.750 --> 00:05:59.690
IT service management has matured.

108
00:05:59.690 --> 00:06:04.922
There is a lot of vendors that
have coalesced around ITIL itself.

109
00:06:04.922 --> 00:06:06.340
ITIL is a safe bet.

110
00:06:07.660 --> 00:06:12.230
Back in the day, good vendors, very good
vendors, had provided good tool sets for

111
00:06:12.230 --> 00:06:14.700
how they envisioned service management.

112
00:06:14.700 --> 00:06:18.050
Maybe they were really good at managing
tickets at the service desk and

113
00:06:18.050 --> 00:06:20.520
turning them into problems,
and managing change.

114
00:06:21.950 --> 00:06:25.150
But they weren't necessarily using the
same vocabulary in their tool sets that

115
00:06:25.150 --> 00:06:28.590
maybe ITIL does vver
the years that has evolved.

116
00:06:28.590 --> 00:06:33.720
Again, ITIL is the world's single best and
most widely adopted service management

117
00:06:33.720 --> 00:06:39.870
practice, therefore tool vendors
have caught up with that reality and

118
00:06:39.870 --> 00:06:44.780
are now positioning their products
to be ITIL-aligned, right?

119
00:06:44.780 --> 00:06:45.690
So that's good news.

120
00:06:45.690 --> 00:06:50.450
Another part of the good news is that as
you're developing your tool set strategy,

121
00:06:50.450 --> 00:06:52.080
you should consider future growth,

122
00:06:52.080 --> 00:06:55.820
not necessarily future functionality but
future growth.

123
00:06:55.820 --> 00:06:59.900
The scale of your tool sets now could
be challenged in the future, right?

124
00:06:59.900 --> 00:07:04.290
So build in a little bit of scalability
into your tool selections, but

125
00:07:04.290 --> 00:07:06.210
in terms of functionality,

126
00:07:06.210 --> 00:07:10.260
the good news is there's a lot of tool
vendors out there that understand ITIL,

127
00:07:10.260 --> 00:07:13.759
use the language of ITIL, and
understand the challenges of integration.

128
00:07:14.990 --> 00:07:16.560
So, just be careful of that.

129
00:07:16.560 --> 00:07:21.651
Use tried and trusted vendors, one's
that's got some road wear if you will,

130
00:07:21.651 --> 00:07:26.205
they've been in this game for a while or
have shown some good vendors,

131
00:07:26.205 --> 00:07:31.145
I'm sorry, some good customer bases,
and have some experience with it and

132
00:07:31.145 --> 00:07:33.093
you'll make some safe bets.

133
00:07:33.093 --> 00:07:36.095
>> Now Terry, that does sound like
a lot like some of the concepts that I

134
00:07:36.095 --> 00:07:38.620
understand from project
management as well.

135
00:07:38.620 --> 00:07:43.282
That, even though we can take a look at
them, it does seem like some of those

136
00:07:43.282 --> 00:07:48.255
skills do transfer over and kind of help
me understand ITIL a little bit better.

137
00:07:48.255 --> 00:07:53.225
So is there a good way to take some of the
things that I might have learned to help

138
00:07:53.225 --> 00:07:57.827
transfer those over and to make sure
that everything integrates well.

139
00:07:57.827 --> 00:08:02.412
>> Project management as a discipline does
marry up well with service management

140
00:08:02.412 --> 00:08:03.459
as a discipline.

141
00:08:04.520 --> 00:08:07.420
Risk management, for instance,
is a big key of project management.

142
00:08:07.420 --> 00:08:09.990
It should be a big part
of service management.

143
00:08:09.990 --> 00:08:13.550
Looking ahead, predictive,
understanding resource constraints,

144
00:08:13.550 --> 00:08:18.280
understanding cost constraints, these are
disciplines that project management has.

145
00:08:18.280 --> 00:08:23.970
And typically they apply those for
a project that has a beginning and an end.

146
00:08:23.970 --> 00:08:25.860
The only subtle difference,
and significant difference,

147
00:08:25.860 --> 00:08:29.240
I shouldn't say subtle, significant
difference between project management and

148
00:08:29.240 --> 00:08:32.700
service management, is service
management doesn't really have an end.

149
00:08:32.700 --> 00:08:33.550
It's cyclical.

150
00:08:33.550 --> 00:08:34.619
It is a circle.

151
00:08:34.619 --> 00:08:37.740
And it's a cycle of improvement
all the time, right?

152
00:08:37.740 --> 00:08:40.350
So while project management
circle brings a lot of discipline

153
00:08:40.350 --> 00:08:44.160
to the game of service management,
service managements adds to that game

154
00:08:44.160 --> 00:08:49.260
by making sure there's a continual and
gradual churn for improving services.

155
00:08:49.260 --> 00:08:53.120
>> Now when we start to,
to pick up on this idea of services and

156
00:08:53.120 --> 00:08:56.950
everything that we need as well as
kind of a comprehensive system here.

157
00:08:58.460 --> 00:08:59.650
Where do we begin?

158
00:08:59.650 --> 00:09:04.160
Is it important that service operations
really has a part in strategy and

159
00:09:04.160 --> 00:09:05.240
transition?

160
00:09:05.240 --> 00:09:09.180
Or do we just say, hey top down,
here's a nice strategy just implement it.

161
00:09:09.180 --> 00:09:13.730
>> Yeah, there's somewhat again,
kind of an answer within your question.

162
00:09:13.730 --> 00:09:17.430
It would be folly for service strategists

163
00:09:17.430 --> 00:09:21.680
to make a decision without considering
the downstream stages, right?

164
00:09:21.680 --> 00:09:25.160
I believed in ITIL researches,
this librarian went out,

165
00:09:25.160 --> 00:09:29.740
I say librarian the writer of ITIL is they
went out and try to define best practice.

166
00:09:29.740 --> 00:09:33.020
They found that highly
functioning service organizations

167
00:09:33.020 --> 00:09:36.890
involved operational folks at
all stages of the life cycle.

168
00:09:36.890 --> 00:09:40.510
So, and then they codify that in
the writing of their best practices and

169
00:09:40.510 --> 00:09:41.880
their recommendations.

170
00:09:41.880 --> 00:09:46.890
So, a strong recommendation from ITIL
is to involve service operations early

171
00:09:46.890 --> 00:09:48.090
and often.

172
00:09:48.090 --> 00:09:50.740
We've been talking this week about
release, control, I'm sorry,

173
00:09:50.740 --> 00:09:54.050
in these episodes, in release,
control, and validation, right?

174
00:09:54.050 --> 00:09:59.620
So, while that scope was somewhat narrow
to the changing of existing services,

175
00:09:59.620 --> 00:10:02.030
operations still needs
to be involved in that.

176
00:10:02.030 --> 00:10:04.550
There is an operational
churn with change and

177
00:10:04.550 --> 00:10:07.650
those operational people know
that churn better than anybody.

178
00:10:07.650 --> 00:10:11.560
They understand those impacts perhaps
better than anybody else because they're

179
00:10:11.560 --> 00:10:14.530
on the ground feeling
the pain of failed changes.

180
00:10:14.530 --> 00:10:18.010
They're on the ground feeling
the benefits of successful changes.

181
00:10:18.010 --> 00:10:21.400
They're the ones that are going
to be delivering it ongoing.

182
00:10:21.400 --> 00:10:25.390
So, involve the shares operations
people earlier than later is key.

183
00:10:26.430 --> 00:10:30.490
>> What are some of the other types
of planning that we have to consider

184
00:10:30.490 --> 00:10:33.350
when we're talking about this idea
of the additional technologies like

185
00:10:33.350 --> 00:10:34.790
licensing and deployment?

186
00:10:34.790 --> 00:10:36.020
What else do we need to consider here?

187
00:10:36.020 --> 00:10:37.290
>> Yeah, thanks for this.

188
00:10:37.290 --> 00:10:42.590
This topic is not particularly exciting,
but you can get some

189
00:10:43.850 --> 00:10:48.040
good recommendations from other
practitioners and other services.

190
00:10:49.440 --> 00:10:52.160
Licensing, just how do you wanna
think about your licensing?

191
00:10:52.160 --> 00:10:55.174
You're gonna buy a tool set,
how many people are going to be using it,

192
00:10:55.174 --> 00:10:57.899
do you want dedicated licenses,
do you wanna share licenses?

193
00:10:57.899 --> 00:11:02.562
Do you wanna have something called a web
license, where some people can access this

194
00:11:02.562 --> 00:11:07.830
tool set and a lot cheaper price but
only get some of the functionality right?

195
00:11:07.830 --> 00:11:11.630
Or is it gonna be service on demand in
fact some of this tools sets are actually

196
00:11:11.630 --> 00:11:16.360
externally hosted and they are intended
to be scaled as you grow right?

197
00:11:16.360 --> 00:11:19.150
So there's lots of options in
this pages related to scale,

198
00:11:19.150 --> 00:11:21.940
related to cost savings, etc.

199
00:11:21.940 --> 00:11:25.050
ITIL is certainly not
prescriptive in this regard and

200
00:11:25.050 --> 00:11:28.900
the options available views that comes out
on an exam are going to be fairly obvious.

201
00:11:29.942 --> 00:11:35.170
>> All right, so along with this then,
let's then focus in on the idea of some

202
00:11:35.170 --> 00:11:39.940
of the critical success factors that
we want to make sure that we go over.

203
00:11:41.270 --> 00:11:44.790
>> Fair enough, as we concluded
the discussion on each of these seven

204
00:11:44.790 --> 00:11:46.890
processes in release control validation,

205
00:11:46.890 --> 00:11:50.550
we focused on the critical success
factors of those processes.

206
00:11:50.550 --> 00:11:54.040
I think it's also important to focus on
the critical success factors of service

207
00:11:54.040 --> 00:11:55.780
management at large and

208
00:11:55.780 --> 00:12:00.130
this really does mean that you're gonna
be focusing on business outcomes.

209
00:12:00.130 --> 00:12:02.940
We've also preached that
throughout these episodes as well.

210
00:12:02.940 --> 00:12:06.970
Is that whatever you are doing, you need
to have the focus that is going to add

211
00:12:06.970 --> 00:12:11.050
benefit and
value to your customers, right?

212
